scenes.location: TAXI. NEW YORK CITY. NIGHT., (APRIL 1953) APRIL 1953
characters: INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. DAY
EXT. TWO-LANE HIGHWAY OUTSIDE OF PITTSBURGH. NIGHT
INT. MIDTOWN RESTAURANT. DAY. MOMENTS LATER
INT. MOTEL ROOM. OUTSIDE PITTSBURGH. DAY
INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. BAR/LOUNGE. MOMENTS LATER
INT. JERRY RIX LAW OFFICES. DAY. MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of the darkness, the screeching moan of an arriving train. A dark swarm of bodies file out of the LEXINGTON a 59TH ST STATION. We descend upon the crowd, singling out young man in coat and hat, JACK TAFT, late 20s, who weave through the line of COMMUTERS, some opening umbrellas to patchy skies. JACK buys an evening paper at a newsstand a makes his way across 59th. EXT./INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. NIGHT. JACK enters the hotel and we follow him as he walks throu the lobby to the bar. JACK easily finds a stool, nods to BARTENDER and tosses him the newspaper. The BARTENDER poi to a bottle of Dewars and JACK gives him a thumbs up. He scans the cocktail lounge adjacent to the bar - not much activity in there, either: a FEW TABLES OF BUSINESSMEN getting drunk, an ELDERLY COUPLE, TWO WOMEN tucked away i corner table. JACK checks his watch and the BARTENDER set down his drink.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Not much going on for a Friday.

dialogues.speaker: BARTENDER
dialogues.text: It’s early yet. JACK downs his scotch, slides his empty glass over to the BARTENDER, taps out a rhythm along the edge of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Say Cal, make it a double, would you? And one for yourself. I gotta make a call. JACK gets up. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. BAR/LOUNGE. NIGHT. JACK makes his way through the lounge on his way to a telephone booth. He takes another look at the TWO WOMEN tucked away in the corner, deep in conversation, and thin he recognizes one of them. He begins approaching them.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Therese? Is that you? THERESE, the younger of the women, turns to look at JACK.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What do you know! (he starts over) I'm saying to myself, I know that girl. It seems to take her a split second to react, to stand a greet JACK with a short hug.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Gee it’s great to see you, Therese. It’s been, well, months.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Months. The OTHER WOMAN at the table lights a cigarette. THERESE glances at her, and they hold a brief, tense look before THERESE remembers her manners. THERESE (CONT’D) Jack, this is Carol Aird. JACK holds out his hand. CAROL shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Likewise. CAROL retreats back to her own thoughts, smokes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey, Ted Gray’s meeting me here and a bunch of us are heading down to Phil’s party. You’re going aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Well - yes. I just planned to get there a little...(looking to Carol)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You should go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You coming along?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, no. (to THERESE) I should make a few calls before dinner, anyway. I should really run.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to JACK) Well... it would be great to catch a ride. CAROL takes a step towards THERESE, but no more.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You two have a wonderful night. Nice meeting you, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you. And she’s gone. THERESE doesn’t move, doesn’t turn around watch CAROL leave.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, well let me go make sure the loaf is on his way. Back ina flash. JACK takes off. A beat before THERESE turns and scans the and beyond for CAROL. But she’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. BAR/LOUNGE. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: JACK, through the glass of the phone-booth door, is finis his call. He emerges from the booth, passing the bar on t way, where the bartender spots him, and holds up the pape

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Keep it! JACK returns to where he left THERESE but stops when he doesn’t see her, glancing around. He’s about to ask a WAI if he’s seen her when he spots THERESE emerging from the ladies lounge. She looks pallid.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There you are! Thought you ditched me. You alright? He said he’d meet us out front. INT. /EXT. NYC TAXI CAB. NIGHT. THERESE sits against the window in the back of a taxi, crowded with JACK and OTHER 20-somethings, MALE AND FEMAL all involved in animated conversation we can’t hear. The stops for a light and THERESE catches sight of an ELEGANT COUPLE, arm-in-arm at the corner, crossing the avenue as light changes. A strong gust of wind gives the woman some difficulty as she tries to knot a green silk scarf around head.  As they reach the sidewalk, she turns back to face the avenue, and then recedes, swallowed by swirling lights an reflections.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: BRIEF SHOTS (INT. TOY DEPARTMENT - FRANKENBERG’S) A toy train whizzes by the faces of miniature pedestrians a department store display. CAROL AIRD, seen from a dista in winter coat, stands watching. She wears a green silk s over her head, loosely tied. She turns, smiles. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. EAST 50'S. DECEMBER 1952. MORNI An alarm blares over the sleeping face of THERESE BELIVET huddled under covers. THERESE doesn’t stir though the ala continues. Finally, THERESE, in one skilled manoeuver, pu herself up and out of bed, still cocooned within the blankets. She finds the alarm clock and shuts it off. She looks at the alarm clock. It reads 7.00 A.M. THERESE moves through her morning rituals: she throws ope her window shades, moves on to a small gas stove, strikes match and lights the stove to take the chill off, moves o the kitchen sink set in one corner of the room, which dou as a partial home darkroom - developer and fixer trays stacked to the side of the sink, an Argus C3 camera from late 1930s set on a shelf above the sink, along with a collection of red or amber light bulbs and photo paper. The room is sparsely furnished, and much of the wall spac taken up with THERESE’S B&W photos, mostly NY CITY STREET SCENES and URBAN LANDSCAPES. THERESE is brushing her teet when the doorbell rings. Once. Twice. Three times. She sh her blankets and goes to the window, opens it, leans out. EXT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. CONTINUOUS. THERESE’S boyfriend, RICHARD SEMCO, looks up at her from street, striding his bicycle. He’s well-bundled in scarf hat.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I like your scribbles. RICHARD looks around to the street behind him covered in children’s chalk scribblings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah - I’ve been busy! (grinning at her): I don’t know how you look a million bucks first thing in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I won't be a minute. EXT. CENTRAL PARK. NY CITY. MORNING. RICHARD rides THERESE to work through the park. She sits her arms wrapped around his hips while he stands pumping at the pedals.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So I got the schedules. In the mail. You listening to me?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m listening! You got the schedules.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: And there are two sailings to France in June, one in July.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: So whaddya think?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I think... I think it’s so cold I can’t think straight.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Oh yeah? Well let’s get you warmed up. RICHARD accelerates. THERESE laughs, holds on tighter. RICHARD begins to sing: “I love Paris in the... summer-ti as they speed away. EXT. FRANKENBERG’S DEPARTMENT STORE. MORNING. Outside the employee’s entrance, RICHARD and THERESE stan a longish line of MOSTLY YOUNG STAFF waiting to begin the work day. Everyone looks exactly the same: a lot cold, a little Soviet-factory-worker glum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway she wants to make it for you so there’s no use fighting it, once she gets an idea in her head... She's just going crazy with no girls in the family but Esther- A SECURITY GUARD has opened the door and the line has beg to move. Upon entering, each employee is handed a Santa Cap, which they dutifully put on. RICHARD reaches the door, takes hi cap, wordlessly puts it on, moves inside. He holds out a to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: SECURITY GUARD
dialogues.text: Compliments of the season from the management. THERESE takes her cap, doesn’t put it on, moves inside.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I gotta open the floor. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE CAFETERIA. MORNING. From a table in the corner, THERESE sips at a cup of coff and watches a sea of Santa-capped and uniform-smocked STA move wordlessly along the breakfast line, accepting gooey eggs and cups of coffee. THERESE looks down at a Frankenberg’s employee handbook. We glimpse bits and piec of information: ...2 weeks vacation after 5 years, 4 week vacation after 15 years... full pension, benefits...” She turns a page: “Are YOU Frankenberg Material?” It’s too depressing to take in. THERESE slips the handboo back into her purse and removes a copy of Joyce’s “Portra of the Artist as a Young Man.” But just as she settles in ROBERTA WALLS, an officious supervisor in bright red harlequin glasses, swoops by THERESE planting a Santa cap firmly onto her head.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA WALLS
dialogues.text: You're needed upstairs, Miss Belivet. Make it snappy. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL STOCK ROOM. MORNING. THERESE, surrounded by rows of identical Christmas dolls, counts stock. THERESE watches a very middle-aged, wheezin employee, RUBY ROBICHEK, struggle with carrying seven or eight large boxes across the stock room floor. RUBY can’t in front of her, and as she attempts to peer around the e of the boxes, most of the boxes tumble out of RUBY’S arms onto the floor. THERESE quickly determines she’s the only help on the fl and goes to assist RUBY, who has great difficulty in knee to pick up the boxes.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (kneels to help RUBY) Please- let me help. RUBY is grateful to avoid kneeling, and places each box THERESE hands to her on the display counter.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: Thanks an awful lot, honey. I keep telling them upstairs we need more stock boys come the holidays, but they haven't listened in 18 years.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You’ve been here 18 years?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. And when you're here long enough, you’1l get inventive with juggling boxes, like me.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m just a temporary. For the holiday.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: (shrugs) I said that once. INT. FRANKENBERG'S. TOY DEPARTMENT. MORNING. Just before opening: a surreal calm and silence. THERESE, Santa cap, and makeshift bandage, stands beside an elabor model train set. She flips a switch and the train set com to life - the tiny lights, the tinny whir of the engine a the train chugs its way along the track. A LOUD BUZZER sounds. Behind THERESE, we can see the analogue lift indicator start to move: 5th floor, 4th floor, 3rd floor. as the lift descends to accept its first load of daily customers and a voice bellows from the intercom:

dialogues.speaker: STORE ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Good morning, Happy Holidays and welcome, shoppers, to Frankenberg’s. Be sure to take advantage of our Congratulations Ike and Mamie Inaugural Early Bird special in our Beds and Bedding Department on the second floor. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on your way there, you won’t want to miss our brand new General Electric television and stereophonic display on the first floor, just past the haberdashery. Behind THERESE, the lift doors open and all at once THERE is swallowed up by the rush of MANAGERS, STAFF and CUSTOM INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DEPARTMENT. LATER THERESE sits behind a display case full of dolls. She tri to make herself invisible while she surreptitiously reads book. The department is full of MOTHERS buying Christmas gifts for their children. THERESE’S reading is interrupte a SHARP WAILING. She looks up to see a TODDLER throwing a tantrum and an EMBARRASSED MOM trying to get the situatio under control. Just then, ROBERTA WALLS bustles through t department, sees THERESE, points to THERESE’S head - wher the Santa cap? ROBERTA WALLS seems to say without saying THERESE hurriedly stashes her book into her handbag and p out the cap. She tries to hide the bloodstains. ROBERTA W nods to THERESE and moves on. THERESE settles back down, bored. A CUSTOMER looks expectantly to THERESE; THERESE pretends she doesn’t see CUSTOMER and ducks down to her handbag to retrieve her bo She looks up above the desk to see where the CUSTOMER wen and instead spies a glance of another woman - a woman who green silk scarf tied loosely around her neck and head catches THERESE’S attention. This WOMAN appears to be the only customer surrounded by no one else. This is CAROL AI CAROL bends down to examine the train set, and inadverten toggles the on/off switch - the train shuts down. CAROL stands up, turns around towards the doll department, smil as if asking for help. THERESE meets CAROL’S eyes for a strange split second - u the EMBARRASSED MOM and the screaming TODDLER appear in f of THERESE, blocking her view of anything else.

dialogues.speaker: EMBARRASSED MOM
dialogues.text: Where’s the ladies room, honey?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: To the left, past men’s shoes, then right at the tie racks. EMBARRASSED MOM nods her thanks and hoists TODDLER away. THERESE looks for CAROL, but she’s no longer there. The t set is back on, and being admired by several sets of FATH and SONS.  INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DEPARTMENT. MOMENTS LATER Behind and below the desk, THERESE contemplates sneaking read of her book, but decides against it. She glances bac and sees a pair of black leather gloves tossed onto the d THERESE looks and sees CAROL standing before her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m looking for a doll. She’s about- (she gestures)- this high and this wide and... (rethinking): Let's begin again, shall we? As CAROL steps away from the desk a moment to rummage thr her purse, THERESE can’t stop staring - at her well-tailo suit, her blonde hair, her green silk scarf. CAROL produc crumpled slip of paper, steps back up to the desk, gives THERESE a big smile as she hands it to her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wonder if you might help me find this doll for my daughter. THERESE reads the slip of paper.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Bright Betsy. She cries.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh she does?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: And wets herself. But we’re out of stock.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’ve left it too long. She begins to rummage through her purse.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: We have plenty of other dolls. All kinds, umm... THERESE, suddenly tongue-tied, turns toward the doll disp which CAROL turns to as well.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Right. What was your favorite doll when you were four? Do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Me? I never... Not many, to be honest.  10 CAROL raises a cigarette to her lips, begins to light it, THERESE interrupts. THERESE (CONT’D) Sorry. No smoking on the sales floor.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, of all the - forgive me. (beat) Shopping makes me nervous.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: That's okay. Working here makes me nervous. CAROL laughs, appreciating THERESE’S commiseration.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're very kind. Their eyes meet for a moment, before CAROL rummages insid her purse again. She produces a billfold, opens it, shows to THERESE. It’s a photo of RINDY, CAROL’S 4-YEAR-OLD DAUGHTER.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: She looks like you. Around the mouth. The eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (glancing at THERESE) You think so? THERESE looks up, clocks CAROL watching her, looks down. bit of an awkward moment that CAROL rescues:

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what did you want? When you were that age?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (no hesitation) A train set.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Really. That’s a surprise. (beat) Do you know much about train sets?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I do actually. And there’s a new model, just in last week. Hand- built with hand-painted cars - it’s a limited edition of five thousand, with the most sophisticated electric switching system - it’s quite...  11 THERESE checks her own enthusiasm, noticing CAROL’S eyes her. THERESE (CONT ’D) You may have seen it. Over by the elevators? Just there- THERESE points towards the train set and CAROL turns to l mulling it over. THERESE watches her every move.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (turns back to THERESE) Do you ship?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Special delivery. Or courier. (beat) You'll have it in two, three days. Two days. We’ll even assemble it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well. That’s... that. Sold. They stand there, nodding at each other for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Shall I pay now?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Oh - yes, of course. THERESE begins writing out a sales slip, then slides it o to CAROL with a pen, glancing up at her. CAROL snaps out brief moment of thought, a distance. THERESE (CONT’D) We'll need your account details, your shipping address.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Of course. (she begins writing) I love Christmas. At least I love the preparation. Wrapping gifts, all that. And then... you somehow wind up overcooking the turkey anyway. She finishes, flashing a bright smile. THERESE doesn’t qu follow her, but she doesn’t want CAROL to stop talking. CAROL (CONT’D) Done. CAROL hands the pen and sales slip back to THERESE. CAROL (CONT’D) Where’d you learn so much about train sets, anyway?  12

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I - read... Too much, probably.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It's refreshing. Thank you. (beat) And Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. CAROL walks away. THERESE watches her, takes her all in - manner, her style, her walk. CAROL turns back for a momen and points to THERESE’S cap.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I like your hat. THERESE watches her go off past the train set and elevato For a moment she watches as the empty spaces left behind filled by shoppers and staff. She cranes her neck for one last look but it’s no good. She’s gone. THERESE sighs. Sh looks down at the doll desk and sees that CAROL has left gloves behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THERESE stares out the window, still wrapped up in though Up front, JACK is pointing out the West Village apartment building ("Here-here-here!”) and the taxi screeches to a halt. Everyone tumbles out as JACK pays the driver. Befor she knows it, THERESE is climbing the stairs to PHIL McELROY’S building. A window is thrown open above them an PHIL McELROY, with typically unkempt hair, leans out.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: It’s about time, Belivet. Say hello at least - It hasn’t been that long!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Hello - Phil - sorry, I was... DANNIE, PHIL’S brother, leans out of the window next to P

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: There she is! Get up here! (picking up on her state): What?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Nothing! There better be beer. Or wine.

dialogues.speaker: OTHERS
dialogues.text: Or beer!  13 Someone rings THERESE and the others in. It makes an anno sound - a buzzing sound that makes THERESE frown, and as moves up the stairs and into the building we

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE LOCKER ROOM. EVENING. THERESE stands at her open locker, as the BUZZER indicati that the store is closed blares incessantly. She takes of her Frankenberg’s smock and puts on a pair of dark tights that she’s just bought, to cover up her bandage. It does trick. She puts on her coat, scarf, etc. The inside of he locker door is decorated with photographs THERESE has tak shots of THERESE and RICHARD in Coney Island. As THERESE CAROL'S gloves into her handbag, the BUZZING finally stop She can see RUBY ROBICHEK at her locker across the room, pulling on some winter boots with great difficulty. THERE quickly dabs on some powder and shuts her locker. INT. CINEMA PROJECTION ROOM. NIGHT. THERESE, RICHARD, PHIL and DANNIE McELROY sit crowded together in the small dark space, watching a movie throug the modest glass panel, smoking cigarettes. THERESE sits RICHARD’S lap, but RICHARD is more content kissing the ba of her neck than watching the film. PHIL McELROY, the fil projectionist and host, sits near the gears while his brother, DANNIE, sits as close as he can to the movie, jotting down occasional notes in a small notebook. The fi is Sunset Boulevard, and the scene is Norma Desmond’s New Year's Eve party for two when she dances with Joe Gillis the marble ballroom floor. THERESE is fascinated by DANNI but PHIL slaps him on the back of his head.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Move over. Nobody else can see the screen.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (through his nuzzling of

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Nobody else is watching.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (laughs) I’m watching.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (to THERESE) I’ve seen it six times. I’m charting the correlation between what the characters say and how they really feel.  14

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: My kid brother, the movie jerk. DANNIE, embarrassed, moves slightly away from the glass. he still watches, still jots notes. THERESE watches him. INT. GREENWICH VILLAGE BAR. NIGHT. RICHARD and PHIL have been drinking quite a bit. A row of empty beer bottles is lined up on the table in front of t DANNIE sips at a glass of Coca-Cola. THERESE nurses a gla of wine.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: I'm strictly a beer man. Everything else makes me want to vomit.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Wine makes me feel naughty. In a good way.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Is there any other way to feel naughty?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I drink to forget I gotta get up for work in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: That’s your problem, Semco. You really ought to drink because you remember you have a job. Employment’s a curse.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You have a job, Phil.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: You call that a job? I call it an illusion.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: You get paid. Is money an illusion?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: My kid brother, the jerk philosopher.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (to Dannie) Where do you work?  15

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (mock respect) Didn’t you know - Dannie works at the New York Times. RICHARD and PHIL feign awe.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (she’s impressed) No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Yeah, ‘cept printers don’t win Pulitzer Prizes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (he shrugs) It’s a job. (to THERESE) What I want to do is write. That’s why I watch movies.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: (rolling his eyes) Everybody's a writer.... DANNIE tries to blend into the woodwork. He catches THERE eye. She smiles at him. He appreciates it.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Say, Therese - before I get too drunk to remember.... PHIL digs into a large messenger bag, pulls out a camera, old Kodak, and hands it to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You did it? It’s fixed?

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: He said it was a cinch. No sweat.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Thank you, Phil! I was missing it!

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: So, you take pictures?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Well.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: She's more excited by some chintzy camera than she is about sailing with me to Europe!

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: Women!  16

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You said it, pal! RICHARD and PHIL laugh, toast, drink. THERESE isn’t amuse DANNIE clocks this. EXT. THIRD AVENUE. NIGHT. THERESE walks with DANNIE. RICHARD and PHIL, now very dru and rowdy, walk slightly ahead of them, with RICHARD guid his bicycle unsteadily along the pavement.

dialogues.speaker: PHIL
dialogues.text: What you oughta do is hit Spain... whatsitcalled - Pamplona. Catch a bullfight! Up ahead a couple is approaching who everyone knows: JACK TAFT and his girlfriend, DOROTHY. The men all speak to ea other as DOROTHY speaks to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: JACK PHIL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Holy smoke, look who's I don’t believe it! Does the coming. Watch out, baby, it’s House Un-American Activitie a pack of commies! know you're back on the streets?

dialogues.speaker: DOROTHY THERESE
dialogues.text: Terry, honey, it’s been ages. Hey Dottie. Hasn’t it? I Call me, would you? will, I promise! RICHARD turns around as they pass, walking unsteadily backwards with his bicycle.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: That son of a bitch... You still owe me for that poker game!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Richard, watch out, you’re-! But she’s too late to save RICHARD from backing into a lamppost. He falls down, the bicycle topples down on top him. PHIL attempts to help but tumbles onto RICHARD, and both dissolve into a fit of drunken laughter.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (to THERESE) Europe. Wow. You’re lucky.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Am I? A beat as they watch PHIL and RICHARD make a meal of gett up.  17 THERESE (CONT’D) We should help them.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) You should come to the Times for dinner some time. I work at night, so... I’ve got a good pal who’s a junior photo editor. He loves to pontificate. I’1l introduce you.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Really? That - I would - I’d like that.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (pleased) Yeah? Okay, then. And they’ve forgotten all about RICHARD and PHIL. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATE NIGHT. THERESE and RICHARD lie together side by side in bed. THE is fully clothed. RICHARD wears a tank-top undershirt and boxers. They are engaged in a pretty passionate embrace. RICHARD starts to unbutton THERESE’S blouse. She stops hi gently. He rolls on top of her. Again, she stops him. RIC rolls off THERESE, sits up. He takes her into his arms, kisses her nose.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Let me touch you.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Let me.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You sure? THERESE nods her head. RICHARD takes THERESE’S hand and places it on his boxer shorts, over his cock. RICHARD (CONT’D) This okay? She nods. RICHARD moves her hand inside his boxer shorts. puts his hand over hers and begins to guide her into a ha job, slow and steady.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Like that? RICHARD lets go of THERESE’S hand and leans back, closes eyes. He lets out a low moan.  18 THERESE watches RICHARD intently the whole time, as if sh more an observer than a full participant. RICHARD’S breat rapidly quickens.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (as he comes) I love you, Terry. RICHARD relaxes. THERESE pulls her hand out of RICHARD’S shorts. She looks down at the semen on her hand. RICHARD up, takes off his vest, switches off the light. RICHARD (CONT’D) Jesus, Terry, you shouldn’t look at it. RICHARD laughs, wipes THERESE’S hand with his undershirt throws it onto the floor. THERESE laughs, too. RICHARD le forward, kisses THERESE deeply, tenderly. THERESE pulls a suddenly.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Shit, I forgot your aspirin. THERESE jumps out of bed and runs to the bathroom. RICHAR exhausted and happy, falls back onto the bed. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATE NIGHT. RICHARD is asleep. THERESE sits at her small kitchen tabl THERESE holds CAROL’S gloves and the sales slip from Frankenberg’s with CAROL’S name, address and signature ne written on it. She considers the slip for a moment before propping it up against a salt shaker with the gloves. She draws her knees into her chest and rocks herself to and f She watches RICHARD sleep. EXT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATE NIGHT. THERESE stands in front of a postbox, wearing a coat over night clothes. There’s not a soul in sight in the cold ni She looks at a small package addressed to “Mrs. H. Aird” a moment before dropping it into the postbox. She looks u her window a moment before being seized by a chill and running up the stoop to her building. EXT. SUBURBAN NEW JERSEY STREET. LATE MORNING. A MAILMAN pulls up to a large stone house with a gabled r along the stately residential street. He grabs a handful mail, jumps down and begins walking up the driveway.  19 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. ENTRANCE. LATE MORNING. Mail is dropped through the letter slot, including THERES package to CAROL. FLORENCE, CAROL’S housekeeper, glances to the entry while mopping the floor. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CAROL’S BEDROOM. LATE MORNING. CAROL sits with her daughter RINDY, age 4, at CAROL’S van CAROL is brushing RINDY’S hair, as RINDY counts along, pretending to powder her face with a powder puff.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Fifty-three, fifty-four, fifty- five...(she looks up at her mother) sixty?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (kisses her forehead) Fifty-six.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Fifty-six. Fifty-seven... CAROL hears the sound of her husband’s arrival downstairs

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That must be your daddy. We’d better finish up. Fifty-eight, fifty-nine-

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Come skating with Daddy and me!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, I wish I could, sweet pea.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Why not, mommy? Pretty please! HARGE, CAROL’S husband, appears in the bedroom doorway. H carries the pile of mail.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (to RINDY) Hiya, sunshine. CAROL looks up. She sees HARGE reflected in the vanity mirror. RINDY turns, sees him, jumps down from her mother lap and runs to him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're early.  20

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Mail came. HARGE waves it vaguely before setting it down on an end- table.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Daddy! I want Mommy to come skating too! She leaps into his arms. He spins her around. CAROL hasn' moved from the vanity.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Okeydokey, smokey, one thing at a time. He puts RINDY down. Catches sight of CAROL staring at him puts the mail down onto the vanity. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. LATE MORNING. CAROL, HARGE and RINDY in the kitchen. RINDY sits on HARG lap. She’s using crayons to draw a picture. FLORENCE prep a hot meal in the background.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: How ‘bout some green for the trees?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: She loves to color in the sky first.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: And Cy’s wife asked if you were coming-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (he does this every time) -Jeanette.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: -Jeaneatte. (beat) I know she’d love to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Give her my best. I’ve always liked Jeanette. CAROL checks RINDY’S drawing, slides another color over t her. As she does, HARGE slides a hand over CAROL'S.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: I'd like you to be there.  21 CAROL looks at HARGE’S hand on hers. She looks up at him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Harge. I have plans.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Mommy and Aunt Abby are exchanging presents. HARGE smiles, nods, pats CAROL’S hand, withdraws his hand turns his daughter around in his lap to face him.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: You been seeing a lot of Aunt Abby lately, sunshine? With mommy? CAROL shoots HARGE a look. He holds her gaze, not giving CAROL looks away, uncomfortable in FLORENCE’S presence.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’1ll - try and re-arrange with Abby.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. INT. FRANKENBERG’S DEPARTMENT STORE. SHIPPING DEPT. DAY. A SHIPPING CLERK sorts through his file of carbon shippin receipts while THERESE stands at the window. THERESE (CONT’D) I told the customer it would get to her by Christmas Eve. Based on what we've been told. Three business days from the-

dialogues.speaker: SHIPPING CLERK
dialogues.text: (looks up at her) Should have been delivered this afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Oh. Right. So... It arrived? She signed for it?

dialogues.speaker: SHIPPING CLERK
dialogues.text: (all curt business here) It arrived.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Great. Thanks - thank you.  22 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CAROL’S BEDROOM. NIGHT. CAROL sits before her dressing table brushing out her hai lit cigarette burns down in an ashtray on the dressing ta A tumbler of scotch on the rocks rests beside the ashtray CAROL puts down the brush, and glances down at her lap. T she holds the gloves she’d left at Frankenberg’s and a no from THERESE. She takes a drag of the cigarette and reads note again: Salutations from Frankenberg’s Department Store. Employee 645-A. She crumples up the letter and tosses it into a small was basket. She takes another drag on her cigarette, then gla back at the waste basket. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DESK. THE NEXT DAY. LATE AFTERNO THERESE at her desk is being exhausted by a PICKY FEMALE CUSTOMER. A score of open doll boxes and dolls are sprawl across the desk.

dialogues.speaker: ROBERTA WALLS, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Belivet? Miss Belivet? THERESE looks up. ROBERTA WALLS stands at a desk nearby, crooking a finger at THERESE and holding a telephone rece up. ROBERTA WALLS (CONT’D) Over here please. Now? She snaps her fingers for another SALES CLERK to take ove from THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (to CUSTOMER) Sorry - I’m - excuse me. THERESE hurries over to ROBERTA WALLS as the SALES CLERK takes over the PICKY FEMALE CUSTOMER. ROBERTA WALLS hands receiver to THERESE and shoots her a withering look. THER takes the phone. THERESE (CONT’D) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Is this employee 645-A, Tereeza Belivet?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes.  23

dialogues.speaker: OPERATOR, (0.S)
dialogues.text: We're patching you though, ma‘am. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. LATE AFTERNOON. CAROL cooks dinner as she makes her call, which helps her combat some of her residual shyness. A radio is tuned in some BIG BAND MUSIC.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: So it was you. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DESK. LATE AFTERNOON. THERESE on the phone. WALLS, stony-faced and staring.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Oh - hello. Mrs. Aird? Did you - receive the train set alright? INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. LATE AFTERNOON.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I did. And the gloves. Thank you so much. You’re a star for sending them. I just called to say - thank you, really.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Of course. CAROL picks up a saucepan lid but it’s too hot and she dr it. It clatters on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, shit - sorry. What I mean to say - Do you get a lunch hour there? - Let me take you to lunch. It’s the least I can do. INT. FRANKENBERG’S. DOLL DESK. LATE AFTERNOON. THERESE blinks. Hard. She holds a long breath before replying, mindful of ROBERTA WALLS attuned to her every w

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I - well. Yes, of course. But you really don’t- (pause) Tomorrow? (pause) No, I don’t know it. Hold on. (sheepishly to ROBERTA) I'm sorry. Can I borrow a paper and a pencil?  24 ROBERTA WALLS isn’t happy as she slides a paper and penci over to THERESE. THERESE quickly scribbles down an addres INT. MIDTOWN RESTAURANT. DAY. THERESE stands at the front of a small midtown restaurant with white tablecloths and wooden rafters. She glances up the clock which reads 1:12 and checks it against her wristwatch. She glances out the window. There, through beveled glass, she spots CAROL hurrying across the street

dialogues.speaker: INT. MIDTOWN RESTAURANT. DAY. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: CAROL and THERESE are seated at a quiet table. CAROL is removing her hat, glancing at her menu as a WAITER hovers THERESE sits transfixed, her eyes quick and alert, taking everything about CAROL from the way a delicate gold brace falls against her wrist as she peruses her menu to the wa CAROL'S fingers grip her water glass.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m so sorry to keep you waiting. (to the WAITER) I’1l have the creamed spinach over poached eggs. And a dry martini. With an olive. CAROL and the WAITER look to THERESE, who realizes she ha even opened her menu. A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I‘1l have the same.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: The meal or the drink?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Uhh - All of it. Thank you. The WAITER nods, starting off, as CAROL clocks THERESE’S uncertainty. THERESE not wanting to stare at CAROL, now p up her menu and thumbs through it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Cigarette? CAROL offers THERESE a cigarette from her exquisite silve case. THERESE notices that CAROL’S hands are lovely and smooth, salon manicured, in contrast to THERESE’S own. THERESE takes a cigarette from the case. CAROL lights THERESE’S cigarette and THERESE proceeds to smoke it, tho not without some effort.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what kind of a name is Belivet?  25

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It’s Czech. It’s changed. Originally-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s very original.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (she feels herself blush) Well.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And your first name?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Therese.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Therese. Not Ter-eeza.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Therese Belivet. That’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: And yours?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Carol.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol. The WAITER reappears with their drinks and CAROL picks up glass and toasts.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Cheers.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (clinking glasses) Cheers. CAROL sips at her martini. THERESE watches her for a mome then samples hers. She tries to hide the surprise of its strength. CAROL smiles. THERESE (CONT’D) (beat) So, you - I’m sure you thought it was a man who sent back your gloves.  26

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I did. I thought it might be a man in the ski department.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, I’m delighted. I doubt very much if I’d have gone to lunch with him. THERESE watches as CAROL massages the back of her neck fo moment.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Your perfume -

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It’s nice.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Harge bought me a bottle years ago, before we were married. I’ve been wearing it ever since.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Harge is your husband?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes. Well. Technically we - We’re divorcing.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (stubs out her cigarette) Don’t be. THERESE doesn’t know what to say. CAROL smiles, changes t subject.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And do you live alone, Therese Belivet?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I do. (beat) Well, there’s Richard. He wants to live with me. CAROL looks up at THERESE, raised eyebrow smile.  27 THERESE (CONT’D) No, it’s nothing like that. It’s - he'd like to marry me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I see. Would you like to marry him? A pause.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (she makes light of it) I... barely know what to order for lunch. CAROL nods, almost looks past THERESE - what is she think about? Suddenly it seems to THERESE that CAROL’S mood has somehow darkened. The WAITER appears with their food. He sets their plates down. CAROL picks up her silverware, the cloud seemingly past.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m starved. Bon appetit. CAROL eats and THERESE watches, almost having to force herself to pick up her fork and knife and join her. But s does. CAROL looks up at her for a moment:

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And what do you do on Sundays?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Nothing in particular. What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nothing - lately. If you’d like to visit me some time, you’re welcome to. At least there’s some pretty country around where I live. Would you like to come out this Sunday? CAROL waits for THERESE’S answer.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What a strange girl you are.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Flung out of space.  28 THERESE feels herself blush, and looks away from CAROL. S tries to attend to her lunch and martini. EXT. RESTAURANT. DAY. Through passing CROWDS, THERESE watches from just outside restaurant entrance as CAROL climbs into a convertible ac the street. CAROL’S best friend, ABBY, drives. She and CA greet each other with European-style kisses. Then CAROL t around and waves to THERESE. THERESE waves back as the ca takes off, disappearing into traffic. INT. ABBY’S CAR. DAY. ABBY snakes along Sixth Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I can just see Harge’s mother’s face when she sees me in this. Maybe I should stop home and change.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Don’t be a stupe.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why don’t I just not show up?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Because I’1l be blamed. So you'd better just grin and bear it. (beat) You want to tell me about her? CAROL and ABBY exchange a brief glance.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Therese? (shrugs) She returned my gloves.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And... if you don’t get us out of this traffic soon, I won’t have to worry about any damned party. (bundling up): Do you ever put the top up?  29 INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE LOCKER ROOM. DAY. THERESE sits opposite her open locker, now wearing her employee smock. She writes inside an appointment diary, o otherwise empty page, slowly and carefully in fountain pe Mrs. Carol Aird. Seventh Avenue entrance. 2:00 PM Sunday. She considers what she’s written, blows on the ink so it dries. EXT. NEW JERSEY. WEALTHY SUBURBS. EARLY EVENING. A well-kept road full of wealthy homes, green, sweeping l old wealth. ABBY’S car pulls into the circular drive of a large modern home, set back against a cloak of trees - th residence of HARGE’S boss, CY HARRISON. There’s clearly a party going on: music, laughter, well-dressed GUESTS arriving, valets opening doors, taking keys, etc. ABBY sh off the engine and turns to CAROL, who begins rummaging through her purse in sudden agitation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where on earth is my compact. God damn it. ABBY leans over towards CAROL, touches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You look fine. CAROL looks at ABBY.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Come in with me. Just for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Don’t even start. You’re the one who cancelled on us - you nitwit!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I know. I know. I’m sorry - I’m going! CAROL looks towards the house again, gathering herself.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Call me later. INT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. DEN/LIVING ROOM - EARLY EVENING A large room for entertaining right off the foyer. Big, o fireplace. WAITERS circulate with food and drink. HARGE stands in a group with his parents, JOHN and JENNIFER, hi boss CY and CY’S wife, JEANETTE.  30

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to CY) I've tried to talk sense to the boy, Cy. I told him, son, Tri-State Capital’s not going to buy that Murray Hill parcel unless you improve your golf handicap.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (to his father, slight edge) I've got a few other things on my mind, Dad. A reserved silence, as they all know to what he’s referri HARGE looks off, sees CAROL in the foyer, handing her coa a VALET. HARGE (CONT’D) Excuse me. And he makes his way through the GUESTS to join CAROL. INT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM - NIGHT The party in full-swing. A DANCE BAND plays “Harbour Ligh and HARGE and CAROL dance a slow fox-trot. CAROL notices other women, dressed much more formally than she. HARGE clocks this and draws her closer to him.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: You're always the most beautiful woman in any room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Tell your mother that. They look across the room to see JENNIFER watching them, indeed, looking as if she’d just swallowed a clove of gar INT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. BUFFET/DINING ROOM - LATER Carol and Harge, and Cy and Jennifer are moving through t dinner buffet with their plates. JENNIFER hovers, tidying the display, and handing stray glasses and napkins to members of the staff.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: We might hire a local boy to appear as Santa for Rindy, Christmas morning. If only we could find a way to get him down the chimney! (beat; to CAROL) How've you arranged it in the past, Carol?  31

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What’s that?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Christmas morning. With Rindy. CAROL exchanges a brief look with HARGE before answering.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, we... usually get up at dawn, Harge and I, and we - we wrap Rindy’s gifts together. Arrange them under the tree and wait for Rindy to wake. Which is - she normally-

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (helps CAROL out) Usually, she’s down the stairs ina shot and barely notices us before she’s ripped through all the wrapping.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (smiles, grateful to

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Yes. That’s right.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: But no Santa Claus.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Oh. Well. It is a production - May I serve you? JEANETTE offers CAROL a commiserating look: oh-brother. EXT. CY HARRISON’S HOUSE. LATER. CAROL and JEANETTE in the gardens. The party can be seen going on through a row of French doors. They smoke cigarettes. CAROL takes off her shoes, rubs her feet.

dialogues.speaker: JEANETTE
dialogues.text: (takes a long deep drag on her cigarette) Keep an eye out, will you? Cy’1l scream if he catches me with this.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (laughs) What’1ll he do? Dock your allowance?  32

dialogues.speaker: JEANETTE
dialogues.text: (very matter of fact) He doesn’t like me to smoke.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: So? You like it. But they both know that it’s simply the way it is: wives defer to their husband’s wishes.

dialogues.speaker: JEANETTE
dialogues.text: Carol, I - it’s really not my business, but if you’re going to be alone on Christmas, Cy and I would love to have you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (she’s really touched by the offer) Thank you, Jeanette. CAROL takes another look inside the party: couples dancin through the tented plastic.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (watching the dancing) I don’t know. I might get away by myself. At least for a few days. INT. NEW YORK TIMES. PHOTO DEPT. OFFICE. NIGHT. DANNIE ushers THERESE into the alluring world of a junior photo editor's office: the contact sheets dangling from l boards, the professional equipment, trays and lenses - bu mostly it’s the photos themselves that she’s in awe of. Candids, crime scenes, sports photos, everything that mak up the visual narrative of a newspaper. DANNIE sits at a and sets up dinner, a makeshift array brought from home - wrapped sandwiches, bottles of beer. THERESE breathes it in, not daring to touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, nothing’s gonna break if you pick it up. You want a sandwich? THERESE shakes her head, picks up a contact sheet and a magnifier and glances at the pictures. DANNIE watches her DANNIE (CONT’D) What are your pictures like?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: They’re - probably not very good. I don’t know.  33

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: I mean, what are they? What are they of?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Trees. Birds. Windows. Anything, really. (beat) What do you write about?

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: People. A pause. THERESE looks through a camera lens at DANNIE. H looks up at her, she lowers the lens.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I feel strange, I think... taking pictures of people. It feels like - an intrusion or a-

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Invasion of privacy?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes. DANNIE opens a beer, holds it out to THERESE. She takes i

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Yeah but, all of us, we have, you know - affinities for people, right? THERESE doesn’t answer. DANNIE (CONT’D) Or certain people. There are certain people you like...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Sometimes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: And others you don’t. And you don’t really know why you’re attracted to some people and not others, the only thing you know is - you either are attracted or you’re not. It’s like physics - bouncing off each other like pin balls.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (smiles) So now you're a scientist?  34

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Just trying to explain why I write about people rather than trees.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Sounds more like psychology.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Physics is more comforting. THERESE grabs a sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yeah, but... Not everything’s as simple as a bunch of pin balls reacting, or...

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Some things don’t even react. But everything's alive. A beat. DANNIE moves to THERESE, takes the beer bottle aw from her, puts it down. He puts his hand on THERESE’S shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It’s late. I should go. He kisses her, and she lets him, remaining very still. Th DANNIE steps back and THERESE looks down. THERESE (CONT’D) You shouldn't...

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Why? Did you mind?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Would Richard mind?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Probably. (beat) I have to go. THERESE gathers her things together, goes to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Come back tomorrow? Or Wednesday?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don’t know. THERESE leaves.  35 EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LATE NIGHT. HARGE has brought CAROL home from the party. They stand together outside the door while CAROL fishes for her keys HARGE reaches into his pocket and produces his, opens doo

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thanks. And thanks for staying sober and driving me home. (kissing his cheek) Goodnight, Harge. She starts to go inside the house. HARGE stops her gently

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Come to my parents for Christmas. We had a nice time tonight.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (not unkindly) It was one night.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: I don’t like to think of you. Alone.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not alone. There’s Rindy, there’s- She stops herself. HARGE knows what she was about to say.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Abby. There’s always Abby.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (after a pause) Abby and I were over long before you and I were over, Harge. (beat) I‘1l have Rindy packed and ready for you at four on Christmas Eve. She starts to step inside the house.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: It shouldn't be like this.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I know. And she quietly shuts the door on HARGE.  36 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. The living room is dark and quiet. RINDY has fallen aslee the sofa; FLORENCE, on a chair opposite. CAROL gives FLOR a pat on her shoulder and squats down beside RINDY.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: She wanted to wait up for you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Ah, mama's special girl. CAROL brushes a strand of hair away from her eyes. She ge picks her up and carries her out of the room and up the stairs.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Florence. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. LATER CAROL lifts a holiday blanket from a small platform, revealing the assembled train set, set up behind a couch. switches on the train and watches it begin its slow route along the tracks. She sips at a nightcap. EXT. FRANKENBERG’S. SEVENTH AVENUE ENTRANCE. EARLY SUNDAY AFTERNOON. THERESE, in coat, scarf and gloves, waits for CAROL’S car pull up outside. RICHARD waits with her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Where’s this place in Jersey?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: The country, I think. I don’t really know.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: My uncle Sal lives in Union City and he claims it’s pretty dangerous out there at night-

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It’s not Union City.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. CAROL pulls up to the curb.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: There’s my ride.  37 RICHARD accompanies THERESE to the car. He opens the door her, she gets in, shuts the door, rolls down the window. leans down to kiss her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Eight o’clock?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Eight o’clock. RICHARD looks into the car, holds up a hand in greeting t CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello. Carol Aird.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (leans across THERESE to shake CAROL’S hand) Richard Semco. Glad to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Likewise.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (to RICHARD) She wanted to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Therese speaks very highly of you.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (pleased to hear it) Well, that’s - swell. So you'll... get her back safe and sound? CAROL smiles, salutes her assent. THERESE is slightly embarrassed. RICHARD leans into the car and touches THERESE’S chin lightly. RICHARD (CONT’D) Love you. But THERESE has already rolled up the window, the car has started to go. RICHARD diminishes through the rear window INT. CAROL’S CAR. APPROACHING LINCOLN TUNNEL. DAY. CAROL and THERESE make their way cross town, as a cool wi sun combs through the car windows. CAROL appears at home behind the wheel - relaxed, confident.  38 To THERESE, the world inside CAROL’S car is a revelation, from the tan leather upholstery and mahogany dashboard to effortless style and elegance of its driver. The sounds o the world - even CAROL’S occasional chatter - have been replaced with the stillest MUSIC, the sound of air and li The presence of this older, sophisticated woman, who wear silk stockings and expensive perfume, is intoxicating and unnerving in equal measure. Even Carol’s purse, which res beside THERESE on the seat, is quite unlike anything she seen or examined so closely, full of mystery and make-up fragrances. From there her eyes wander down to CAROL’S le clad in smoky silk stockings. Glancing down at her own le wrapped in sensible wool tights, THERESE wonders if she w ever be the kind of woman who owns such a car and wears s clothes. The MUSIC broods slightly as THERESE looks straight ahead the car enters the Lincoln Tunnel. The car plunges into t semi-darkness as if entering a cocoon, a delirious descen which binds them together. She watches CAROL’S fingers gr the wheel, how CAROL squints slightly when she concentrat THERESE can barely suppress a tiny smile. But glancing ba CAROL suddenly appears to be miles away. CAROL switches o the car radio and Jo Stafford’s “You Belong to Me” comes THERESE leans back in her seat as they continue, speeding through the dark tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: AS WE RETURN TO
dialogues.text: INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. (APRIL 1953) “You Belong To Me” also plays as several COUPLES DANCE, a them RICHARD and a PRETTY YOUNG WOMAN who he clutches tightly. THERESE, drinking a beer, watches them from a hallway just outside the living room. RICHARD catches sight of THERESE, tensing slightly, befor spinning his partner up and away from THERESE’S view. THE looks down, pulling out a cigarette from her purse and lighting it. She spots an attractive dark-haired woman on opposite side of the living room whose eyes are clearly o her. THERESE holds her gaze for a few seconds, but she ca feel herself blush, and she looks down. When she looks ba up, the WOMAN has disappeared. THERESE saunters a bit, glancing into the next room where she spots DANNIE and hi girlfriend LOUISE slow-dancing. They barely move, holding to each other the way people do when they’re newly in lov

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: 39 INT./EXT. CAROL’S CAR. XMAS TREE LOT. NEW JERSEY. DAY. At a Christmas tree lot, THERESE sits in the car loading camera with film. When she’s done, she spots CAROL outsid a TEENAGED BOY ties up their tree, a large Doug Fir. The TEENAGED BOY has a bad cold and CAROL offers him tissues. THERESE steps out of the car, aims her camera and takes a shots. INT. CAROL’S CAR. RIDGEWOOD, NEW JERSEY. DAY. The car makes its way to Carol’s house, with the Douglas laid across the front and back seats between THERESE and CAROL. THERESE loves the feeling of the needles against her skin the way it smells, the way she knows that CAROL is beside her, though she can’t see her. The car comes to a halt in front of CAROL’S house. It’s a big house, a bigger house THERESE has ever been inside. CAROL turns off the engine.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You still with me?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes. CAROL opens her door, pops out of the car. THERESE is abo to get out of the car when she sees the front door of the house open and RINDY come tearing out to greet her mother FLORENCE stands in the doorway, ready to escort mother an daughter inside.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: Mommyyyy!!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hello, my darling! Guess what I brought you? I bet you’ll never guess... THERESE watches as mother and daughter proceed inside, chattering away. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. DAY. LATER. THERESE prepares a tray of tea and cookies. Through the o door we can see CAROL and RINDY in the living room, decorating the tree. Almost finished, CAROL is setting up ladder beside the tree.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Where’s the star?  40 RINDY roots around in the pile of ornaments, finds it.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: This one, Mommy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That's my girl. THERESE watches as CAROL ascends the ladder and places th star at the top of the tree.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Look how beautiful! CAROL descends the step ladder and joins Rindy, taking he into her lap.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you ever seen a more beautiful tree? And now... what comes after the star is placed?

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: More stars!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (tickling RINDY) I don't... think... so!

dialogues.speaker: O/S FLORENCE
dialogues.text: You find everything you need, miss? THERESE, startled, turns to see FLORENCE standing at the of the kitchen, near a back door.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Gosh, you scared me. How silly.

dialogues.speaker: FLORENCE
dialogues.text: (she’s not sorry) I’m sorry, miss. (beat) I'1l take that through for Mrs. Aird. FLORENCE picks up the tray, walks through to the living r INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. NIGHT. A fire crackles in the fireplace as CAROL, seated under t tree, struggles to wrap the train set. THERESE sits at th piano, improvising, jumping from one bit of a tune to another. A half-empty bottle of white wine and a couple o glasses stand nearby.  4l

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Were those pictures of me you were taking? At the tree lot? THERESE stops playing. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. I should have asked.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t apologize.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’ve been trying to... A friend of mine told me I should be more interested. In humans.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And how's that going?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (after a small beat) Well... actually.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m glad. THERESE begins to play “Easy Living.” CAROL listens for a moment, rises, walks over to Therese.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s beautiful. She grazes her hand on Therese’s shoulder. THERESE freeze and CAROL tries to lighten the moment with two quick stro to her cheek. THERESE continues to play and CAROL listens

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is that what you want to be? A photographer?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I think so. If I have any talent for it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Isn't that something other people let you know you have? All you can do is - keep working. Use what feels right. Throw away the rest. THERESE finishes the song. CAROL starts over to a table b the couch, opens a cigarette box, takes one out, lights i

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you show me your work? (she sits on the couch)  42

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Sure. I mean, I haven’t sold anything. Or even shown a picture to anyone who could buy one. I don’t even have a decent camera. But... they’re all at my place. Under the sink, mostly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Invite me round. From outside, the sound of a car pulling into the drivewa Car door opens and slams. The moment broken, CAROL rises quickly, and marches toward the front door. CAROL comes out of the living room and finds HARGE in the entry, restringing the mistletoe.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harge. What’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Nothing. Does there have to be a problem for me to visit my wife? HARGE approaches CAROL, reaching out to greet her, but st spotting THERESE at the piano in the living room. He look CAROL and CAROL looks away. Then HARGE moves past CAROL d the hall and into the kitchen. THERESE clocks it all. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. LATER. THERESE browses through a book, alone in the living room, she hears CAROL and HARGE conversing in the kitchen. Thro the cracked door she catches glimpses of CAROL pacing to fro, anxiously smoking, and hears the sounds of HARGE repairing a pipe under the kitchen sink. She tries occupy herself, perusing titles of books from the bookshelf.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: ... that’s not fair, Harge. We agreed that Rindy would stay with me until Christmas Eve.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: What do you suggest I do? - You think I prefer traipsing off to West Palm Beach for the holiday? It was all mother’s doing-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: But I’m not - ready - She’s not packed - she’s asleep in bed! What about my Christmas with my daughter-

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, Carol, but it can’t be helped. The flight’s in the morning - You think I've packed?... (the sound of dropped tools)-Goddamnit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. CONTINUOUS. HARGE emerges from beneath the sink, having hurt his hand CAROL goes to help him up. But as he does he spots THERES through the door. He marches over and opens it fully. THE looks caught, startled. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: How do you know my wife?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Harge, please...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I - work at Frankenberg’s. The department store.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I ordered a gift from her desk. I forgot my gloves. She returned them. I thanked her.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (to CAROL) That’s bold. HARGE sizes THERESE up for a moment before he turns back the kitchen. He walks past CAROL and exits into a cloakro at the back of the house where we hear sounds of his clea up. CAROL, exasperated, approaches the living room doorwa

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Can I - do-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just... leave it be. CAROL gently shuts the door. THERESE is left standing the shut out. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. NIGHT. A UNIFORMED CHAUFFEUR sits at the wheel of Harge’s car, a and silent, as CAROL bundles RINDY into the back seat. FLORENCE puts her bags in the trunk as HARGE waits with a cigarette and drink outside the front door.  44

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Remember: in bed by seven. I know how you take advantage of Grandma Jennifer. (beat) Okay, snow flake. Gimme a big one. (she hugs RINDY tightly and kisses her) You're going to have the most wonderful Christmas, I promise. RINDY pulls back from the hug. She has an idea.

dialogues.speaker: RINDY
dialogues.text: There’s room for you in the car, Mommy. You can come with us!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh, darling, I - wish I could... but sometimes... Mommies and Daddies decide there isn’t enough room for them both in the same place at the same time- (unable to go further) And Mommy has to be here to make sure Santa’s elf doesn’t give your presents to another little girl. You wouldn’t want that, would you? RINDY gives her a bright smile and CAROL hugs her, and ki her eyelids. CAROL clocks the CHAUFFEUR watching her thro the rear view mirror, and quickly looks away. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. CONTINUOUS MUSIC PLAYS softly from the phonograph ("El Americano” by Xavier Cugal and his Orchestra) as THERESE tidies up, try to make herself useful. She can see CAROL through the bay window, shutting the car door and starting back toward th house, wearing only a thin sweater around her shoulders. She sees HARGE step off of the front porch, stub out his cigarette, and walk towards CAROL. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. CAROL heads to the front door, but HARGE pulls her back towards him. A silence, as he takes her hand in one of hi He can hear the MUSIC from inside the house. He sways a little.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: You smell good.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're drunk.  45 He pulls her closer to him, he closes his eyes, tries to dance with her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harge, I’m cold. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. CONTINUOUS. Through the open front door THERESE can see HARGE stumble back slightly, away from CAROL and CAROL grabbing his arm right him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Let me get you some coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (a bit drunk) I’m not drunk. HARGE takes a step towards CAROL. THERESE ducks back into living room, not wishing to overhear any more.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You can still come with us. Go pack a bag.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I can’t do that.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Sure, you can. It’s easy. We can buy you a ticket in the morning. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. HARGE tries to take her hand, she backs away.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: What? You’re going to spend Christmas with Abby? Is that it? Or with your - shop girl?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Stop it, Harge.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: I put nothing past women like you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You married a woman like me.  46 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LIVING ROOM. CONTINUOUS. THERESE goes to the phonograph, increases the volume slightly, so that she can hear only the rising and fallin the voices outside. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. CONTINUOUS. HARGE reaches out to grab CAROL, she backs away. He stumb falls onto his knees. A silence, as he catches his breath

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Come with me now. If you don’t - if you - let me - open that car door - if you won’t come-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (she interrupts him) Then what? Then it’s over? HARGE is about to respond, but he suddenly realizes he’s his hands and knees, drunk, before CAROL, who is very sti and very silent.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Goddamn you - You were never... cruel.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Harge... CAROL takes a step towards HARGE. She cannot bear to see in this state. But HARGE won’t accept her help now. He ri and takes a quick look at his waiting car, RINDY in the b seat. HARGE takes a few deep breaths, smooths his clothes wipes his face with the palm of his hand. CAROL takes ano step towards him. CAROL (CONT’D) I'm sorry. HARGE stiffens, recoils, digs his hands deep into his coa pocket and turns away, striding briskly to his car. CAROL watches as he piles in and shuts the door. The car drives off. CAROL hugs herself tight against the cold. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. EVENING. CONTINUOUS. THERESE hears the front door quietly shut, standing at th phonograph - still, silent. She looks up and CAROL is the watching her, but it’s almost as if CAROL is looking thro her. Then CAROL goes to switch off the phonograph and mov off to pour herself a drink. She opens the cigarette case  47

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I should call a cab.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: And just when you think it can’t get any worse, you run out of cigarettes.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Oh - I - tell me where to go. I’1l buy some for you. Really, I don’t mind-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (snaps) You don’t have to run out in the middle of nowhere to buy cigarettes. Not for me. I’m fine. A pause. CAROL drinks. THERESE covers her upset.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The next train’s at 6.50. I’1l drive you to the station. INT. CAROL’S CAR. NIGHT. CAROL drives THERESE to the station. There’s no one else the road; it’s utterly noiseless. At this moment there couldn’t be more distance between them. INT. TRAIN CAR. NIGHT. THERESE sits against a window as the train speeds its way back to Manhattan. A couple of HOLIDAY REVELERS, laughing tipsy, bump against THERESE’S seat as they make their way through the car. THERESE turns to watch them as they make their way to the end of the car. Their joyfulness is unbearable to THERESE. She makes herself as small as she against the window. She is crying. INT. SEMCO APARTMENT. NIGHT. It’s a warm, ramshackle apartment full of overstuffed, mismatched furniture and bowling trophies. In the kitchen RICHARD washes up a pile of dinner plates while MRS. SEMC sits at the table with THERESE. She takes a thermometer o of THERESE’S mouth and holds it up to the light to read i

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SEMCO
dialogues.text: (refers to the thermometer) What is this number? I can’t read it. My eyes!  48 THERESE reads the thermometer for MRS. SEMCO.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Ninety-eight point six. Perfectly normal. No fever.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You hear that ma, no fever.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SEMCO
dialogues.text: My eyes is no good, not my ears. You wanna plate of noodles, Terry? We saved you a big plate.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m really not that hungry.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SEMCO
dialogues.text: (she’s kidding, but she’s not) I thought you was a smart cookie. You know that’s not the way to a mother-in-law’s heart. RICHARD and THERESE exchange a look. RICHARD’S mother has embarrassed him.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Ma - cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SEMCO
dialogues.text: What? Cut it out what? MR. SEMCO appears in the kitchen doorway. He wears a bowl shirt and carries a bowling bag.

dialogues.speaker: MR. SEMCO
dialogues.text: (to THERESE) You showed up. Good. I was tired of hearing him moan. Do me a favour, Therese. Settle down with him already. RICHARD’S even more embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Come on, what is this? The Inquisition?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (defusing the situation) Okay - I’1l eat. MRS SEMCO beams, pinches THERESE’S cheek.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. SEMCO
dialogues.text: That's my girl!  49 She prepares THERESE a plate. RICHARD and THERESE exchang look. He appreciates her assist. INT. SEMCO APARTMENT. NIGHT. RICHARD’S ROOM. THERESE and RICHARD sit on his bed. THERE holds a wrapped box on her lap.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I can’t open this now. It’s days before Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: But I want you to. (he shrugs) I'm impatient. THERESE unwraps and opens the box. Inside are brochures o France- and two tickets for passage on a ship. The date o departure: March 1, 1953. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Richard... what is this? RICHARD beams, takes one of the tickets from THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Well, that one’s mine. I thought it was more romantic to wrap ‘em up together. THERESE stares at the ticket in her hand, picks up one of brochures full of pictures of Paris landmarks... RICHARD (CONT’D) Jeez, Terry, you could cheer up a little. It’s not every day you get a trip to Europe for Christmas. THERESE looks up at RICHARD.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: We're supposed to go in July.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I know, but - look, I was gonna tell you on Christmas day. Frankenberg’s offered me a promotion. Assistant manager, beds and bedding. THERESE just stares at him, unable to say a word.  50 RICHARD (CONT’D) It’s a big raise. And they’re letting me take a month off in March, two weeks of it paid. The summer’s a busy time there and-

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I can’t go in March.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Why not? You get laid off next week. It’s not like you have any big plans. But this stings THERESE, and RICHARD regrets saying it. RICHARD (CONT’D) I didn’t mean - Terry, you know I think the world of you and - well, I thought you wanted to go to France. With me. And I figured... what the hell, the sooner the better...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I do want to go. I did. (beat) It’s just - soon. March. A silence. THERESE puts the ticket and brochure back into box, puts the lid back on to the box. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BLDG. LATE NIGHT. THERESE can be seen through a window getting out of a cab entering the dark building and wearily climbing the stair As she gets to her apartment door the hall telephone STAR TO RING. THERESE turns, sighs, goes to answer it.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Hello? A door down the hall cracks opens - THERESE’S LANDLADY pe out towards THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: LANDLADY
dialogues.text: Do you know what time it is, Miss Belivet?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry - it just rang... None too pleased, THE LANDLADY shuts her door. THERESE returns her attention to the phone. THERESE (CONT’D) Hello?  51 No one answers. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. BEDROOM. CONTINUOUS. CAROL, on the other line, smokes a cigarette, exhales. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BLDG. CONTINUOUS. Suddenly, THERESE knows who’s on the other end of the lin She closes her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: (after a beat) I was - horrible. Before. Will you forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes... I mean... It’s not-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Then will you - would you - let me come see you... tomorrow evening?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes... Yes. (beat) I want to - know. I think. I mean, to ask you... things. But I’m not sure you want that. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. BEDROOM. CONTINUOUS.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Ask me. Things. Please. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BLDG. CONTINUOUS. THERESE closes her eyes. Silence. Which is suddenly pierc by A GROUP OF YOUNG PEOPLE entering THERESE’S building, g and intoxicated. THERESE is startled, watching them from above, stumbling into the building. By the time she puts phone back to her ear, she knows CAROL’S hung up.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. (APRIL 1953) The party is in full swing - more of a crowd, more LAUGHT boozing.  52 THERESE stands at a window near a SMALL GROUP OF PEOPLE, including GENEVIEVE CANTRELL, the woman she spotted earli THERESE tries to watch GENEVIEVE without being seen as a PARTY GUEST dominates.

dialogues.speaker: MALE PARTY GUEST
dialogues.text: I don’t know, man. You can have her. She’s one of these real Greenwich Village phonies, if you ask me. (to someone else): Where you goin’ Dave? Stick around a minute.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: You're Phil’s friend, aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I am, yes. And Dannie’s.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Aren’t you going to ask me how I knew that?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Aren’t most people here Phil’s friends? GENEVIEVE smiles - touche. THERESE smiles, too, loosening enjoying the flirting.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
