dialogues.text: I can see why Phil speaks so highly of you.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Can you?

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Oh, definitely. I can see a lot.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Really? What do you see?

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: (gives her a good long look) Great - potential. GENEVIEVE hands THERESE a beer, and they clink in a toast THERESE smiles, she enjoys GENEVIEVE’S attention, but she can’t hold GENEVIEVE’S gaze, something about its boldness draws her away from the moment, from the party...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: 53 INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE CAFETERIA. DAY. The employee Christmas party is in progress, which consis of the same old lunch plus Christmas cookies, holiday mus and decorations. THERESE stands next to RUBY ROBICHEK in long line of staff. When it’s RUBY’S turn, the SERVER giv RUBY double of everything in a food box. THERESE notices this, and RUBY sees her notice.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: When you live alone, every penny counts. You economize. You’1l learn.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: How do you know I live alone?

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: (very matter of fact) You got that look. THERESE and RUBY sit at a table. RUBY digs into her purse finds a slip of paper and pen, scribbles down her address telephone number and gives it to THERESE. RUBY ROBICHEK (CONT’D) I know everything there is to know about this place. I’1l fill you in.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m only here a few more days.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: Yeah? Where you going? Macy’s? I knew it! You look like the type who can go swanky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This pleases RUBY and she digs into her lunch with gusto. silence. THERESE watches her eat. She watches everybody e seemingly in unison. THERESE slides her tray over to RUBY

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You take it. I don’t feel like eating.

dialogues.speaker: RUBY ROBICHEK
dialogues.text: You sure? This is good brisket. THERESE nods. RUBY takes THERESE’S meal and shovels it in her food box. RUBY ROBICHEK (CONT’D) You're a good kid. I can get through two, three days with this. THERESE summons a smile in reply, at a loss for words.  54 EXT. MIDTOWN MANHATTAN. SAME DAY. From a distance, we see CAROL'S car pull swiftly into a parking space near FRED HAYMES’ law offices. CAROL gets o of the car and walks briskly down the busy street into th building. INT. HAYMES LAW OFFICES. MOMENTS LATER. FRED HAYMES, CAROL’S lawyer, is just returning to his off when he catches CAROL delivering a small Christmas presen his SECRETARY.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas, Katherine. Ohhh...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s nothing, I assure you. (looks up) Well, there he is. Now will you talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: I didn’t want you to come all the way down here-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Just - give it to me, straight, Fred. What am I not to worry about until after the holiday? They settle inside FRED’S office and FRED closes the door

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Look, Jerry Rix served some papers this morning. To my complete surprise. Why don’t you sit down?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why is it people think you’re going to take bad news better if you’re sitting down? An awkward silence. FRED clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: Harge has sought an injunction which denies you any access to Rindy until the custody hearing. And I'm afraid Harge has changed his mind about joint custody. He wants sole custody of Rindy.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What?  55 CAROL is stunned. She sits. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We've already reached an agreement on custody. What is this all about?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: They'll be filing papers on the twenty-ninth in District Family Court for the, uh, permanent custody petition.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can he do this? Is it - right?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: I don’t know if it’s right, but it’s legal.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: On what grounds.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: (stalling) Listen. Let’s - deal with this after Christmas. You'll have a chance to-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (she interrupts him) On. What. Grounds.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: They're petitioning the judge to consider a morality clause.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: A morality - what the hell does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Okay. I won’t mince words with you. Abby Gerhard.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Abby is Rindy’s godmother. Abby is... (to herself, really) He's... If he can’t have me, I can’t have Rindy - That's...

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. But they seem serious. CAROL looks up to FRED, nods.  A silence. 56

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: When’s the custody hearing?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: It’s hard to say. With the holidays and a backlog of cases...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Your best guess, Fred.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: Not before the middle of March. Could be April.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Can I see her?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: (not unkindly) Not - let me put it this way - It would not be advisable under the-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: At school? In an office with a-?

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYNES
dialogues.text: The issue is not-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Surely a visit supervised by a teacher or a-

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYNES
dialogues.text: Carol, these are serious allegations. Forcing contact before the hearing you simply invite further scrutiny concerning your conduct.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: My conduct! Jesus Christ. I’m her mother for God’s sake. (beat) Morality clause. I see.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYNES
dialogues.text: Do you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No. There’s nothing moral about taking Rindy away from me. CAROL looks back at him in a state of frozen disbelief.  57 EXT. FIFTH AVENUE. SAME AFTERNOON. CAROL reenters the street in a numbing daze. She passes crowds of Christmas SHOPPERS with places to go and things do. She’s not one of those people. She finds herself walk back in the direction of her car through the glare of win light. She puts a cigarette to her lips and begins search through her purse, struggling to find a light. Finally glancing up she is struck by the sight of truck backing o of the lot, and collides with a PEDESTRIAN clearing way.

dialogues.speaker: A VOICE
dialogues.text: Watchit, lady!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Pardon me. CAROL turns into a shop window where she finally manages light her cigarette, taking several deep drags. Looking u she focuses a moment on the display. It’s a vacation them sunglasses on mannequins, cameras slung around their neck luggage stacked in artful piles. She lets her gaze fall o large two-tone brown leather suitcase. INT. RECORD SHOP. EAST 50’S. SAME LATE AFTERNOON. THERESE waits for a requested title at the front counter midtown record store. The STORE CLERK returns with her request: A Billie Holiday album, with “Easy Living” prominently displayed on its cover.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s it, thank you. She hands him a five-dollar bill and he begins ringing he up. As she waits for her change, she spots two SHORT-HAIR WOMEN at the listening station, sharing a single pair of headphones. The more mannish of the two, in horn-rim glas leans against the railing dressed in tailored trousers an jacket over a button-down shirt. The other wears a sleekl tailored woman’s suit, very professional. They are obviou a couple of some kind: New York lesbians. THERESE observe them for a moment, until the woman in slacks looks over - THERESE quickly looks down. EXT. RECORD SHOP. EAST 50’S. RICHARD, waiting outside with his bike, turns to find THE walking briskly out of the record shop.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Let’s walk. I want to drop this at home.  58

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Your wish is my command. They start down the block toward THERESE’s apartment. RICHARD (CONT’D) Find what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (no big deal) Yeah... Something for someone at the store.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You up for the jazz club later on?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Ohh, I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: S'fine. (beat) But you should stop by on Christmas sometime. My Mom’s sort of planning on it.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Christmas... that’s for families. I'd feel - I don’t know...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You are family, Terry. They turn down a small driveway, cutting through an empty lot. THERESE tries to change the subject.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I'm thinking of putting together a portfolio, you know, of my pictures. Start taking portraits, even. Apply for jobs. Maybe at a newspaper. Maybe at the Times. Dannie knows someone--

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Have you been thinking any more about Europe? (no answer) Terry? THERESE stops, brooding, and RICHARD stops and turns to h RICHARD (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: How many times have you been in love?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs, not sure where this came from) Whoa. Never. Until You.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Don’t lie. You told me about those two other girls.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Come on. They were - I had sex with them. That’s not the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Meaning... I’m different because we haven't...(quietly) gone all the way?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No, no - that’s not what I - hey, what’s this all about? I love you. That’s what’s different. THERESE nods. They resume walking.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Have you ever been in love with a boy?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: (after a long beat) No.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: But you’ve heard of it?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Of course. I mean, have I heard of people like that? Sure.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I don’t mean people like that. I mean two people who just... fall in love. With each other. Say, a boy and a boy. Out of the blue.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t know anyone like that. But I‘1l tell you this - there’s always some reason for it. In the background.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: So you don’t think it could just - happen to somebody, just - anybody? 59  60

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. I don’t. What are you saying? Are you in love with a girl?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No. They reach THERESE’S building. RICHARD leans his bike aga a railing, takes THERESE’S hands in his.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Don’t you know I want to spend my life with you, Terry? Come to France with me. Let’s get married.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Richard, I’m not - ready. For that. I can’t make myself-

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What? Tell me.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I just... I have to go.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Terry.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. THERESE runs up the stairs to her building’s front door, is in before RICHARD can say another word. INT. COCKTAIL BAR. SAME LATE AFTERNOON/EARLY EVENING. ABBY and CAROL sip martinis in silence at a favorite join The brown two-tone suitcase CAROL saw in the shop rests against the table. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I found Rindy’s hair brush underneath my pillow this morning. Full of her hair. She does that, you know, to let me know she’s been a good girl and brushed properly. I usually clean it out but - today, for some reason...

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: How could he. How dare he... A morality what?  61

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Clause, he said.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Carol - If I’m responsible in any way-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t you dare - don’t you ever. CAROL downs her drink. She pushes it towards ABBY for a refill. ABBY refills for them both.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Hey. You know that tailor’s shop that went bust in Hoboken?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Sure. The one with the - the - glass thingy on the- CAROL laughs.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Exactly. The glass thingy. That one.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You have no idea what I’m talking about.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You're right. But it’s good to hear you laugh. ABBY offers CAROL a cigarette, she takes it, ABBY lights CAROL leans back in her chair, relaxes.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, the landlord offered me a lease. I was thinking - another furniture shop? I’1l need some help with restorations every once ina while, and you’re the varnish master, SO...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You're serious.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I’m serious. (beat) Couldn’t be any more of a disaster than the shop we had. A silence. ABBY looks away from CAROL. CAROL leans in tow her.  62

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey. We weren’t a disaster. It just... CAROL doesn’t have the words.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I know. Timing. Never had it. Anyway, I’ve got my eye on this redhead who owns a steak house in Paramus. I’m talking - serious Rita Hayworth redhead.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Really? You think you have what it takes to handle a redhead? They share a naughty smile, thinking about serious redhea They toast. ABBY gestures to the suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: West, I was thinking... For a few weeks. Until the hearing. What else am I going to do? A silence.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Well I know you don’t like driving alone. So. (beat; ABBY takes a deep breath, exhales) She's young. CAROL nods her agreement: there’s no denying it.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Tell me you know what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I don’t. (silence) I never did. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. SAME NIGHT. Someone is knocking at Therese’s door. THERESE sticks her head out of her bathroom and looks qui around the room. She hurries out, still brushing her hair fixing her blouse. As she walks to the door she quickly stashes the Billy Holiday record under a pillow, and flip the phonograph (“Smoke Rings," Les Paul & Mary Ford begin play). She takes a last look at her freshly tidied apartm and pulls opens the door. It’s CAROL, the suitcase on the floor beside her.  63

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Your landlady let me in. CAROL lights a cigarette. THERESE can do nothing for a mo but stare. Then THERESE catches sight of the suitcase, wh CAROL pushes across the threshold with her foot.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Merry Christmas. (beat) Open it. THERESE bends down to open the suitcase. Inside is a bran new camera and plenty of rolls of film. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATER. CAROL looks at THERESE’S photographs. She takes her time, really examining them. THERESE watches without crowding h eager for her good opinion. CAROL comes to the photograph THERESE took of her at the tree lot, hung on the wall. Sh moved by it, by the primacy of place THERESE has given.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It’s not that good. I was rushed, I mean... I can do better.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s perfect. Leaning against the end-table, CAROL picks up a small pho in its original cardboard frame: THERESE, aged 5, ata convent school.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes. CAROL puts it down, a bit abruptly, and steps into THERES kitchen sink/dark room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you keep anything in the icebox besides photo chemicals? I’m feeling-

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Sure. THERESE heads to the icebox, where she fishes out a coupl beers. She turns back to find CAROL another step away, fighting back tears. THERESE is frozen for a moment, not knowing exactly what do. She approaches CAROL but hesitates, looking down at t beers in her hand before setting them down on the counter  64 She proceeds gingerly, putting a tentative hand on CAROL’ shoulder, squeezing it. Very quietly, still turned away, CAROL breaks. She lowers her head as THERESE steps closer EXT. THERESE’S ROOF. NIGHT. Sipping coffee from mugs, CAROL saunters along the perime of the roof while THERESE sits on a perch, watching. It’s much of a view, but they can see the tips of the impressi buildings, the lights, the cloudy night sky.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Is there any point in, I don’t know... fighting it?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: The injunction? (beat) No.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Three months. I feel - useless. Like I can’t help you or offer anything-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It has nothing to do with you. A pause. The remark stings THERESE, but she tries to conc it.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m going away for a while.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: When? Where?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Wherever my car will take me. West. Soon. THERESE can’t hide her dismay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I thought... perhaps you’d like to come with me. A beat. CAROL looks directly at THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Would you? A long, held moment before THERESE makes a decision.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I would. A few flurries of snow have begun to fall.  65 INT. FRANKENBERG’S. EMPLOYEE LOCKER ROOM. CHRISTMAS EVE. THERESE is removing her personal belongings from her lock (some stockings, scarves, books) and putting them in her She separates her Frankenberg’s Employee Handbook and her slightly bloody Santa cap and places them in the locker shelf. Down at the other end of the locker room she hears some girls approaching. Beyond them she spots RUBY ROBICH seated on a bench, rolling up her calf-length stockings, looking more weary and alone than ever. THERESE carefully shuts her locker. EXT. FRANKENBERG’S. MOMENTS LATER Through the Christmas display windows we see THERESE exit store with her belongings and hail a cab from the street. the taxi whisks her off we see her glance back one last t INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. CHRISTMAS EVE. DAY. THERESE and RICHARD at the kitchen table. THERESE’S cloth and suitcase are spread out on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I don’t get it. I don’t get it, Therese. Who is this woman to you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: She’s a friend.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I’m your friend, Terry. Phil is your friend - Dannie. This woman - you don’t even know her.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (after a pause) You can forward any mail to Chicago, General Post, but I just paid rent through February. I had a little money saved up for the - for... RICHARD looks up at her sharply. THERESE looks away from

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: For our trip. Our trip, Terry. And now you’re - I don’t believe this is happening!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I can’t explain it. I just -  66

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What? You’ve got one hell of a crush on this woman is what... You're like a schoolgirl!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I do not - I just like her is all. I like talking with her. I’m fond of anybody I can really talk to. This stings him, and they exchange a sharp look.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Nice. You know what I think? I think two weeks from now you’1l be wishing you... She’1l get tired of you and you’1l wish you never-

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: -You don’t understand-!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I do - I understand completely. You’re in a trance!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m wide awake. I’ve never felt more awake. (beat) Why don’t you leave me alone? THERESE has surprised herself with her boldness.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Are we over? Is that what this is?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that. But why should I want to be with you if all you do is argue about this?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: To say - to say for a minute you practically want to say goodbye because of some silly crush!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I didn’t say that. You said it. RICHARD grabs his jacket and starts out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You made me buy boat tickets, I got a better job for you... I asked you to marry me, for Chrissakes...  67 INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY. DAY.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I never made you - I never asked you for - anything. Maybe that’s the problem. As he storms down the stairs, the LANDLADY sticks her hea out of her door, observing the row.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: I swear to you, two weeks from now you'll be begging me to forget this ever-!

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Richard... Richard!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Have a great trip, Terry! He storms out of the building as THERESE starts back to h apartment, receiving the LANDLADY’s glares. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATER. BRIEF CLOSE-UPS: THERESE places clothes in her new suitca She wraps CAROL’s gift. She composes CAROL’s gift card. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. GUEST ROOM. EARLY CHRISTMAS MORNING. THERESE is roused from sleep with the sound of an approac car. She opens her eyes, taking in her surroundings - the comfortable guest room at CAROL’S. She hears voices from outside and turns to look out her window. A fresh layer of snow has fallen and ABBY’S car has pulle the drive, top-down as usual. CAROL can be seen outside, a coat thrown over her robe.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Are you on your way to bed or just getting up?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Both. ABBY tries to stifle a laugh, doesn’t quite. CAROL puts a finger to her lips: “shhh.”

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Go for a ride?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You nitwit.  68

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Well, I had to come see you off, didn’t I?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not alone.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Uh-oh...

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (laughs, then) Come in. There’s coffee. ABBY hops out of the car. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. HALLWAY. MOMENTS LATER. ABBY and CAROL enter the house.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: This place is gloomy as a coal pit in the mornings. They see THERESE sitting at the top of the stairs in her pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We woke you. Go back to sleep, it’s early...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: That’s okay. Can I - come down? ABBY stifles a snort. CAROL ribs her, good-naturedly. THE guardedly watches the way the two interact.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Of course. There’s a robe in the closet. THERESE stands, and ABBY sizes her up.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is Abby Gerhard.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I have no manners.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Absolutely none.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: But it’s nice to meet you, Therese, all the same.  69 THERESE nods, smiling, then slips back down the hall. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. LATER. DAY ABBY is finishing preparing sandwiches which THERESE is wrapping up.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Have you known Carol for a long time?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. A pause while they work.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Did you ever take a trip? With Carol, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Two or three. THERESE can’t quite cover her slight frown. ABBY clocks t

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We had a furniture shop for a couple years, outside Elizabeth. So we were always on the prowl for antiques or second-hand stuff. She grabs a pack of cigarettes from the counter, lights o THERESE watches her. ABBY offers her a cigarette and a li

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You old enough to smoke? A beat, before ABBY breaks a smile, and THERESE decides t smile along.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Okay... A beat, then:

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You know she’s got a lot of worries right now... You know that, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: And she’s lonely.  70

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Is that why she wants me to go with her?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No... ABBY looks out a kitchen window, smokes.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Just - don’t want to see her getting hurt. That’s it.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I'd never hurt Carol. You think I would?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No. (she looks frankly at THERESE)I don’t. THERESE starts putting the food and drinks into a large picnic basket.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: What happened to the furniture store? ABBY sighs. She suddenly looks a little sad to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It was... (resuming her chores): Some things don’t work out, no matter how much you want them to. EXT. CAROL’S HOUSE. LATER. DAY. THERESE and CAROL finish loading up the trunk and wiping last of the snow from the windshield. CAROL slams the tru lid shut, strides to the driver’s side, opens the door, g in. THERESE hurriedly removes the last of the snow from t back windshield as CAROL starts up the car, revving the engine. The hot exhaust creates a swirl of steam as a sof spell of MUSIC rises. THERESE trots up to the passenger s door, taking a last look around before jumping into the c INT CAROL’S CAR / EXT ROAD TO PENNSYLVANIA. LATER. DAY. MUSIC continues over shots inside the car: THERESE pourin coffee for CAROL from the thermos - piping hot and pre- creamed. THERESE lighting two cigarettes and handing one CAROL, as they drive through the black and white of the s thruway towards Philadelphia.  71 INT. PHILLY DINER . LATER. CAROL and THERESE eat tomato soup and crackers, virtually alone in the dreary city diner. A few dismal strands of tinsel and garland, strewn about for holiday effect, surr a green and red cardboard banner which reads: MER Y CH TM THERESE puts aside her meal, gazes out of the window at t largely deserted city streets.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I could get used to having a whole city to myself. THERESE turns to CAROL, who smiles in approval at THERESE plan. THERESE can’t wait any longer, reaching under her s and producing her nicely wrapped gift for CAROL. THERESE (CONT’D) For you. Merry Christmas.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No - You shouldn’t have. But CAROL is pleased, and THERESE is pleased that she’s pleased.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Open it. She watches CAROL unwrap the package. It’s the Billie Hol record with “Easy Living” on it. THERESE (CONT’D) I played it for you. At your house.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I remember. (beat; she looks up at THERESE) Thank you. THERESE picks up her camera, focuses on CAROL, and snaps picture. CAROL brings her hands up to her face.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh God, I look a fright - don’t -

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You do not, you look... (she leans over and takes them back down)wonderful... Just - stay like that. THERESE realizes she’s holding CAROL'S hands in her own. quickly looks around the diner, feeling slightly embarras but no one else is looking. CAROL clocks this, squeezing THERESE’S hands and gently extricating herself.  72

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you miss Richard?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (she thinks about it) No. I haven’t thought about him all day. Or of home.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Home. THERESE regrets using the word, watching CAROL’s mood dar slightly. INT/EXT. PHILLY DINER. INNER PHILADELPHIA. LATER. THERESE returns from the ladies room at the rear of the diner, walking past a WOMAN IN HER THIRTIES gathering her THREE YOUNG CHILDREN. At first THERESE doesn’t see CAROL, then spots her through the window, at a pay telephone. Sh sees her inserting her change and quickly dialing a numbe HEAR THE RINGS: Once. Twice. Three times. CAROL glances toward the diner window. Through the glass one of the WOM CHILDREN is making faces through the precipitation. Just beyond is THERESE, paying the bill at the counter. CAROL replaces the receiver in its cradle before the call can b answered. THERESE turns to exit the diner and spots CAROL smoking a cigarette. INT/EXT. CAROL’S CAR. NIGHT. CAROL drives. THERESE is sleeping, huddled up against the passenger side window. A blanket partly covers her. RADIO V.O. .»+-and that concludes our Holiday Greetings from President-elect and Mrs. Eisenhower. This is WOR- Pittsburgh wishing you and yours- CAROL takes one hand off the steering wheel and pulls up blanket so THERESE is covered.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TWO-LANE HIGHWAY OUTSIDE OF PITTSBURGH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: CAROL'S car glides along the empty road, behind it, the e glow of the Pittsburgh industrial skyline, ahead of it: p darkness.  73 EXT. ABBY’S HOUSE. NIGHT. We see HARGE rushing out of the rear door of his car, his CHAUFFEUR idling, and rushing up the walk of a dark, brickfront bungalow. INT. ABBY’S HOUSE. Ferocious banging on the front door as ABBY rushes down stairs, tying up a robe as she goes. She opens the door. HARGE, in a state, breathing hard.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: I have to speak to her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: What are you doing? - You're supposed to be in Florida.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) I couldn't do it. I had to - Rindy - she wanted to see her mother on Christmas. Not that it’s any of your business. Just go get her. I know she’s here.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You’ve got some fucking nerve ordering me around. And, no. She’s not here.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: That’s impossible. She’s not home. She’s not with me. She must be with you.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Yeah, you know, Harge, you have a point. You’ve spent ten years making damned sure her only point of reference is you, her only focus in life is you, your job, your friends, your family, your-

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: WHERE IS SHE. (beat; he composes himself) She's still my wife, Abby. I’m responsible for her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Well, you know, that’s some way of showing it, Harge - slapping her with an injunction. I’m closing the door.  74 ABBY starts to close it but HARGE intercepts.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: I love her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I can’t help you with that. ABBY quietly shuts the door. But each remains unmoving a moment, in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MOTEL. OUTSIDE PITTSBURGH. DAY
dialogues.text: THERESE is stepping out of her room with her suitcase, dressed for the day. She walks over to the next room and quietly knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol? When there’s no answer, she tries the door. It’s open.

dialogues.speaker: INT. MOTEL ROOM. OUTSIDE PITTSBURGH. DAY
dialogues.text: THERESE peeks her head into the room, to the sound of run water from the bathroom. She sees CAROL’s overnight case open on her bed, her things spread about the room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Therese, is that you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Would you be a sweetie and fetch my red knit sweater? It’s in the small suitcase. Upper left hand side.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Okay. THERESE finds the case, opens it. She takes a moment to l at CAROL’S clothes in the case before she actually touche them, feeling the fabrics, the silks and cashmeres, takin their powdery smells. Something at the bottom of the case catches her eye. A glint of metal beneath some stockings. removes the stockings, revealing a small, pearl-handled pistol. She reaches out, tentatively, to touch it, just a CAROL calls out from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: O/S CAROL
dialogues.text: Hey, slowpoke...  75 THERESE quickly withdraws her hand and hurriedly replaces CAROL'S clothing. She grabs the red sweater.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Found it. THERESE takes the sweater to the bathroom door and knocks lightly. The door opens, revealing CAROL standing there w a towel wrapped around her. Steam filters out of the bathroom. THERESE hesitates a moment, then hands her the sweater.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Everything all right?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yeah - I’m just - suddenly starving.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (closing the door): I won't be a minute. INT. CAROL’S CAR. ON THE ROAD. DAY. CAROL drives, looking out on the increasingly frozen landscape. THERESE is grabbing a sandwich from a basket o the back seat. CAROL’S packed suitcase rests beside it. THERESE settles back into her seat.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Do you feel safe? With me, I mean?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (laughs) You're full of surprises. THERESE continues thinking, eating her sandwich.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: But - Do you? CAROL glances at her. THERESE holds her gaze. CAROL turns attention back to the road.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: It’s the wrong question.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: But you’d tell me. If something scared you. And I could help. CAROL shakes her head, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m not frightened, Therese.  76 THERESE considers this, then glances back at CAROL, who p out at the open road, the cool winter sun skating across face. EXT. MCKINLEY MOTEL. CANTON, OHIO. DUSK. CAROL'S car pulls into the drive of a small motel with an elaborate and large painted likeness of William McKinley wood billboard. INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL. CANTON, OHIO. DUSK. The front desk of the blonde-wood hotel office. A very pr HOTEL MANAGER assists CAROL, checking in.

dialogues.speaker: HOTEL MANAGER
dialogues.text: Our standard rooms come equipped with stereophonic console radios, or if you prefer, the Presidential Suite is available. At a very attractive rate.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (thinks a moment, then) Two standard rooms should be fine.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Why not take the Presidential Suite? CAROL and THERESE exchange a look. THERESE (CONT’D) If the rate’s attractive... EXT. MCKINLEY MOTEL. CANTON, OHIO. NIGHT. THERESE at the ice dispenser. She’s bundled up in scarf, gloves, overcoat - but wearing bunny slippers. She strugg to fill an ice bucket, shivering.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Can I - hold that for you? THERESE looks up. A tall, affable looking young man with spectacles appears beside her, holding up the lid of the dispenser while she fills her bucket.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Thank you. It’s cold.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: So cold my glasses'’ve fogged clear over.  77

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Thanks again. G’night.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Night. He tips his hat to her and THERESE heads back to her room INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL ROOM. NIGHT. True to its name, framed photographs of William McKinley his wife hang over the twin beds. Also adorning the suite dressing table with a fan-shaped mirror, bedside cabinets gold-specked table lamps, striped wall paper. A record pl on THERESE’s portable turntable, (”Easy Living (1933 vers by Billie Holiday). THERESE sits beside CAROL at the dres table as CAROL carefully applies mascara to THERESE’S las

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t blink. (beat) Now look at you. CAROL turns THERESE around to the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I need lipstick. CAROL chooses a lipstick, gives it to THERESE and watches THERESE applies it. CAROL hands THERESE a tissue. THERESE blots, hands CAROL the tissue. THERESE (CONT’D) Next? CAROL picks up a perfume bottle, hands it to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Would mademoiselle be so kind as to apply at the pulse points only? THERESE applies perfume to the inside of her wrists, the crook of her arms, and her neck. She turns to CAROL. CARO holds out her wrists to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Me, too. THERESE applies perfume to the same spots on CAROL. CAROL closes her eyes, arches her neck back slightly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s divine. Smell that. A beat, and THERESE leans forward to smell CAROL’S perfum  78 INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL ROOM. LATE NIGHT. From her neighboring twin bed, THERESE watches CAROL slee Very gently, she slips out of her bed and sits down silen on the edge of CAROL'S bed, and watches her breath. She quietly lifts a finger and lightly runs it along CAROL’S cheek. CAROL turns over in her sleep. THERESE waits to be sure CAROL won’t wake, then returns to her own bed. INT. MCKINLEY MOTEL OFFICE. MORNING. THERESE is seated in the improvised breakfast room, made of a few mismatched tables and chairs, and a paltry sprea coffee, juice and rolls. She spots the YOUNG MAN from the dispenser pouring himself a cup of coffee, carrying a lar black case. He spots THERESE and smiles broadly.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Good morning. Glad to see you didn’t freeze over or nothing.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You too. Before she can even respond he’s setting down his cup and pulling up a chair. THERESE spots CAROL arriving with a r map, making a beeline to the coffee.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Not the best coffee I’m afraid.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Long as it’s hot.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: What’s in the case?

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Oh. Notions. I’m a - I sell them. Or try to. CAROL arrives opposite Therese and plops down.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Lousy coffee.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: (surprised by her arrival) Sorry- (he attempts to stand)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: We were just chatting.  79

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG MAN
dialogues.text: Name’s Tucker... Tommy.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (extending her hand) Therese Belivet. Carol Aird.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Mr. Tucker sells notions. THERESE makes a gesture to his case, which CAROL regards.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: (brief silence) Don’t really know what notions are, exactly. But they do instruct us to use the word. Says it appeals to women. So... (beat) I did sell a shoe-horn yesterday to a feller in Wheeling.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (trying to help him out) Do you sell lipstick?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: No. But I have a sewing kit. (beat) You don’t need a sewing kit. I can tell. CAROL smiles politely, but returns her attention to the m

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to THERESE) We should make Chicago by five or six, if we get an early start.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: That’s where I’m headed. There’s a short cut across the interstates, knocks two hours off the drive.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Two hours, that’s... That would be great-—

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Can we stop to buy some magazines?  80

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: (reaching for his case) I got Field and Stream... National Geographic?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Popular Photography?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: (a beat as he smiles) Nope. Course not. I am doomed to remain without a sale. THERESE throws a little smile to CAROL, as TOMMY shakes h head. MUSIC picks up, carrying over the following scenes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. OPEN ROAD. LATER. DAY
dialogues.text: The wide open road stretches out before us as CAROL'S car comes gliding by. INT. CAROL’S CAR. LATER. DAY Inside, THERESE enjoys the sweet boredom of nothing but t in CAROL'S company. She scans the radio dial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAROL and THERESE, bundled in coats and scarves, sit on t low branch of a tree, just off the road, sharing sandwich and thermos coffee. ]

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DRAKE HOTEL. CHICAGO. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The shimmering entrance to Chicago’s Drake Hotel is a swa of taxis, GUESTS and BELL-HOPS. CAROL and THERESE, bleary from the road, come to a stop and begin quickly gathering their things from the car. INT. DRAKE HOTEL ROOM. LATER. A BELLBOY carries CAROL and THERESE’S bags into an opulen room. We hear CAROL tip and thank him as we follow THERES into her first encounter with hotel luxury. CAROL collaps onto one of the beds.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Finally. A real bed. Heaven. THERESE inspects the room like a detective. She bends to her hand through the carpet.  81

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: This carpet - it feels like woven silk! Like we shouldn’t be stepping on it. And the furniture! She turns to look at CAROL... fast asleep on the bed. INT. DRAKE HOTEL. RESTAURANT. LATER. Carol speaks to the hostess as Therese observes the busy hotel restaurant, with WAITERS moving briskly and efficie through the room.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Table for two, please, for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Are you staying here at the hotel?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes, it’s room... (she searches for her key)

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: 623. Mrs. Aird.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: That’ll be just a moment, Mrs. Aird.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Therese eyes the gifts and souvenirs at the counter: fanc boxes of candy, souvenir key rings, pens. She lifts a can specialty Virginia ham.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Do you think something like this would appeal to an older woman?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I suppose. Depends on the woman.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I worked with a woman at Frankenberg’s - Ruby. But she depressed me.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: She’s old. Alone. No money. It’s - silly, I know.  82

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I think it’s a lovely gesture. Send it. Here. CAROL picks up the order form and pencil and hands it to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: HOSTESS
dialogues.text: Mrs. Aird, your table is ready.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you. Therese takes the form and pencil with her as they are le their table. INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE. PHONE BOOTH. CHICAGO. DAY. CAROL in a phone booth placing a call. She can see THERES from the booth, who stands in line to collect general delivery mail. INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE. CHICAGO. DAY. CONTINUOUS. THERESE on line to pick up her mail. She looks around for CAROL, spots her dialing in the phone booth... INT. HARGE’S OFFICE. NEW YORK. DAY. His private phone rings. He picks up.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: Hargess Aird. Hello. Nothing from the other end.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All right, Carol. Enough is enough. Now where are you, goddamnit?... Hello? INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE PHONE BOOTH. CHICAGO. DAY. CAROL, suddenly unable to respond, leans her head against phone box a moment, then quietly hangs up the phone. INT. CENTRAL POST OFFICE. CHICAGO. DAY. CAROL joins THERESE at the post desk. THERESE has picked few letters.  83

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (refers to the letters) Someone’s popular.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: All from Richard. (she puts the letters in her bag) Aren't you going to check your mail?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nobody knows I’m here.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Were you... making a call?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What? No - Ladies room. Carol throws her scarf over her head and starts out. Ther watches her a moment as she goes, then follows. EXT. LAKE SHORE DRIVE. CHICAGO. NEW YEAR’S EVE. DAY. CAROL and THERESE stand at the side of the frozen road, considering a flat tire. CAROL starts rummaging through h purse when she looks up and hears a car coming.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Here’s one. THERESE tries to flag down the approaching motorist for h A dark-colored ‘42 Chrysler Sedan slows to a stop and pul over ahead of them. The driver backs up, revealing it to TOMMY TUCKER, the notions salesman.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Well - what in the world. (to Carol): Look who just...

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: What do you know? I thought that might be the two of you. TOMMY hops out of his car and approaches the women. He inspects the tire.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yep, that’s a flat alright. Just hope you didn’t dent that rim.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I felt something pulling, and then a grinding-  84

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: Right. Well. Can I jack her up for you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: We - don’t think there is one.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: No jack?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (glancing at CAROL) We think it might have been left at home.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Long story.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Bigger problem is, we think it might be flat. The spare.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: Gotcha. Well... I got a jack. I can jack her up for you. We just use my spare.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: But what about you?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: Me I’m heading home from here - I got plenty of spares back home. (inspecting the flat) Don’t think there’s rim damage. Shouldn’t take too long I don’t expect.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: There’s just... one other thing...

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: What’s that, ma’am? INT/EXT. TOMMY’S CAR. LAKE SHORE DRIVE. LATER. DAY. In the front seat, THERESE offers CAROL some coffee from thermos. Radio softly plays. Up ahead, TOMMY leans over t hood, his hands black from a lengthy operation.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m ravenous.  Silence. 85

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: So am I.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (watching him work) We're lucky we found him.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’ll say. THERESE (CONT’D) Are you sorry we came?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: On the trip? No. Are you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No. They look up to the sound of CAROL’s car starting up agai TOMMY climbs out of the drivers seat and approaches, dust himself off. CAROL and THERESE get out to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: Well... It’ll get you to your next stop, but you best get it checked at a garage. New hose. They’1l tell ya the same.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Thank you so much.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Tommy, what do we owe you.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: Oh, please - nothing at all, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well for the tire at least.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: No need. Like I said, I’ve got a collection. Occupational hazard.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Well. Thank you. Again. For everything.  86

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: You are surely welcome, ma’am. CAROL starts off to the car, leaving an uncertain beat between TOMMY and THERESE. TOMMY TUCKER (CONT’D) And Happy New Year.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes, that’s right. Happy New Year to you.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: Yep, well, I’m counting on a big night for sales. Stocking up on hats and sparklers. I’m hopeful. THERESE smiles as he back-steps, tips his hat and gets in his car. She glances at CAROL, climbing into the car - an feels a sudden surge of longing. EXT. WATERLOO, IOWA. EARLY EVENING. On the road leading into Waterloo, CAROL’S car speeds by billboard sign with a cartoon of Napoleon being strangled Nelson. In fancy script below the cartoon is written: WATERLOO BECKONS. POP. 12,070. The sky is a deep red. INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. NIGHT. Twin beds, quilted headboards, the usual. Radio tuned int Guy Lombardo’s New Year’s Eve broadcast from the Waldorf Astoria. It’s almost midnight. A couple of chipped plasti trays carrying the remnants of some ham and cheese sandwi are set on one of the beds. CAROL sits sipping beer from Champagne flute, her hair wrapped in a towel. Each dresse robes, CAROL watches THERESE brush out her hair at a dres table. The countdown to the New Year begins on the radio. Five. Four. Three. Two. One: HAPPY NEW YEAR! And the fami Lombardo signature “Auld Lang Syne” begins, but neither w takes notice. Instead CAROL gets up from the bed, takes t brush from THERESE and begins to brush THERESE’S hair, slowly, carefully. When she’s done, she puts the brush do and turns THERESE around to face her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Happy New Year.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Happy New Year. They face each other in silence, listening to the faraway radio broadcast - a moment when anything could happen.  87 THERESE, for the first time, reaches out ever so slightly brush her fingers against CAROL’S. CAROL looks down at th fingertips touching.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Harge and I never spend New Year’s Eve together. There’s always a business function, always clients to entertain.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’ve always spent it alone. In crowds. (beat) I’m not alone this year. THERESE squeezes CAROL'S hand ever so slightly. The Guy Lombardo band strikes up a bright New Year’s tune. CAROL unties her robe and lets it fall open, revealing he nakedness to THERESE. It’s so still, it’s as if all breat the room were suspended. THERESE stands up to join her, a CAROL takes her face gently in both her hands. She kisses THERESE’S lips. It’s a wondrous kiss for them both, slow unhurried. Afterwards, CAROL removes her hands from THERE face and eases off the towel from her head.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: For everything that might happen. Later.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (after a moment) Take me to bed. CAROL moves towards THERESE, takes her in her arms, leads to the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Lie down. THERESE does. CAROL lets her own robe drop to the floor t opens THERESE’s robe on the bed, taking in her youthful beauty.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I never looked like that. She climbs onto the bed and straddles THERESE. She stroke her face, her hair. THERESE closes her eyes, but begins t tremble involuntarily.  88

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're trembling. CAROL leans down to kiss her lightly on the forehead, the reaches across the bed to shut off the light. THERESE sto her.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Don’t. I want to see you. CAROL nods, then slides down THERESE’S body and stops jus below THERESE’S navel. She kisses her belly, moves down THERESE’S body with her mouth. THERESE looks up at the ceiling, trying to quell her body’s shuddering of nerves. closes her eyes. CAROL slides up THERESE’S body and plays with one of THERESE’S nipples with the tip of her tongue. THERESE moans softly. She pulls CAROL up to her mouth and they kiss eagerly, passionately. THERESE opens her eyes a regards CAROL’S face, so close to hers, and smiles.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (a whisper) My angel. Flung out of space. They begin to make love for the very first time.

dialogues.speaker: INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. DAY
dialogues.text: Morning light filters through the drawn curtains as THERE still in bed, watches CAROL packing up for the day ahead. suddenly, this day, everything in the world is different.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: What town are we in?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: This? Waterloo. Isn’t that awful? INT. OFFICE. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. LATER. The deserted office is strewn with empty beer bottles and cheap New Year’s decoration. CAROL looks around for a cle rings the desk bell. An ANCIENT WOMAN shuffles on out of back room. She wears a party hat.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: You the folks in thirteen?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: We're checking out.

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: Telegram come for you last night.  89 The ANCIENT WOMAN shuffles on out of the room and comes b with a telegram. She gives it to CAROL. CAROL opens the telegram. Reads it. It’s not good news.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: When did this arrive?

dialogues.speaker: ANCIENT WOMAN
dialogues.text: I ain’t a clock, lady. Early. Seven. Nine. EXT. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. MORNING. CAROL storms out of the office, tearing past the patchy remains of snow, where THERESE is loading the car with th belongings. CAROL pulls open the driver's side door, searching for something she doesn’t see, and slams the do shut. She runs up to the cabin they just vacated and tear open the door, almost immediately comes out again, slammi shut the door. She’s furious.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol! What the hell-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (focusing on THERESE) Where's my suitcase?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol - wait a minute - what’s going on?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (she snaps) I want my fucking suitcase. CAROL storms over to the trunk, brushing past THERESE on way. She finds her suitcase, flings it open and starts rifling through it. She finds the pistol. THERESE tries t block her way.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: What are you doing with that? Carol - what happened?! CAROL pushes past THERESE. EXT./INT. CABIN. JOSEPHINE MOTOR LODGE. MORNING. CAROL kicks at the door of the cabin next to their’s.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Open up in there! You hear me? Right now!  90 THERESE runs up to the door to join CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol, you're scaring me, you can’t-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Stand out of the way, Therese. Carol reaches for the door and finds it unlocked. She kic the door open and takes aim. TOMMY TUCKER stands inside getting dressed, trousers half on, half off. He wears his hat. He grabs his spectacles off a table and slips them o the end of his nose. On the unmade bed before him is his black case, opened to reveal an elaborate reel-to-reel ta recorder and sophisticated microphones. THERESE stares at equipment, uncomprehending. CAROL cocks her pistol and assumes the shooting stance, aiming directly at TOMMY’S h

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (CONT'D) (to TOMMY) Where’s the tape, you sonofabitch. She enters the room, starts pulling apart the case, the equipment, all the while keeping the pistol aimed at TOMM TOMMY continues to dress himself, rather calmly.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How much is Harge paying you for this? I’1l give you double, triple. Anything you want.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: I wish I could oblige you, ma‘am. But the tape is already on its way to your husband.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That can’t be right.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: (shrugs) My reputation rests on my efficiency, Mrs. Aird. A tense pause. CAROL moves towards TOMMY. He remains quit calm, still. But he keeps his eye on her all the while. C advances closer, aiming the pistol at his head.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: How do I know you’re not lying?

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: (a beat) You don’t, ma’am.  91 CAROL tenses up, putting her index finger on the trigger. at once she whirls around to the recording equipment, poi the gun to it, and pulls the trigger - but the gun just clicks. She tries again, but the trigger jams. In utter frustration she hurls the gun at the recording equipment. THERESE, who’s been hovering by the door, moves towards CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Carol... CAROL, exhausted and distraught, gives THERESE the telegr and moves outside of the cabin. She slumps against the railing. THERESE exchanges a look with TOMMY, who’s still cool as cucumber. THERESE retrieves the gun, joins CAROL outside. CAROL lights a cigarette, looks out towards the highway. THERESE reads the telegram, then looks up through the doo TOMMY, still standing half dressed in his cabin. THERESE (CONT’D) (to TOMMY) How could you.

dialogues.speaker: TOMMY TUCKER
dialogues.text: I am a professional, Miss Belivet. It’s nothing personal. A silence. CAROL smokes, THERESE shakes her head at TOMMY disgusted, not wanting to believe this is happening. TOMM tips his hat to THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Let’s get out of here. EXT. ALLEY. WATERLOO. LATER. THERESE, carrying pistol and telegram, finds some trash b in an alley. She lifts the lid on one and tosses the pist into it, but it lodges on top. She buries it with one han and does her best to clean it off with the telegram. She tosses back the lid and hurries back to the street, round the corner. There she finds CAROL at a pay phone. She ste back instinctively, but overhears the end of CAROL’S call ABBY.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: +. earliest flight into LaGuardia is tomorrow afternoon... Oh Abby, I don’t know how to fix this - I haven't the strength... THERESE wishes she could hold CAROL in her arms at this moment. But she knows she can’t.  92 INT. CAROL’S CAR. EARLY EVENING. CAROL drives in silence as they approach Chicago. THERESE smokes a cigarette. You could cut the tension with a knif

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You shouldn’t smoke. You'll get a cough. (silence) What are you thinking?... You know how many times a day I ask you that?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. What am I thinking? I’m thinking that I am utterly selfish. And I-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t do this. You had no idea. How could you have known?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I - I should have said no to you. But I never say no. And it’s selfish because I take - everything. Because I don’t know - anything. I don’t - know what I want. How could I if I just say yes to everything? THERESE begins to cry, softly. CAROL pulls over to the si of the road, against a frozen bank of snow. She turns THE towards her. She dries her tears. CAROL and THERESE regar each other, calmly, steadily.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I took what you gave willingly. A pause. CAROL runs a finger along THERESE’S cheek. She t back to the wheel. Restarts the car.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not your fault, Therese - Alright? More silence. CAROL, at a loss to make the situation bett accelerates quickly onto the highway. INT. DRAKE HOTEL. CHICAGO. NIGHT. CAROL is finishing a call with ABBY, sitting on one of th twin beds, smoking. THERESE emerges from the bathroom, switching off the light. She stands for a moment in the d before she climbs into the other bed.  93

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you, pet... Oh, you know. Shattered. Sickened... I hope so... No... Talk tomorrow... And thank you... I will. Night. She hangs up the phone and looks down a moment. Then she turns to THERESE with a sad tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You don’t have to sleep over there. Silence. THERESE gets up, joins CAROL in the other bed. C wraps her arms and legs around THERESE, kissing her gentl the eyes, the lips. THERESE looks at her deeply and then kisses her back, a long, lingering, searching kiss. INT. DRAKE HOTEL. CHICAGO. MORNING. A ribbon of daylight over THERESE’s face. Eyes still shut she reaches out for CAROL, but CAROL’S not there. No soun coming from the bathroom. She lifts her head and checks t clock: 8 AM. THERESE sits up in the bed. There, seated in armchair in the semi-darkness, is ABBY. She smokes a cigarette. And all at once THERESE understands what CAROL absence means. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: She’s gone?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Early this morning.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Is she coming back?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: No. Piercing silence.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: This is all my fault.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Nonsense. ABBY puts out her cigarette, gets up and pulls open the curtains. Cold, bright sunlight streams into the room.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We should get going.  94 INT. ROADSIDE DINER OUTSIDE OF CHICAGO. DAY. THERESE stares out the window; she hasn’t touched her mea

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Eat something. (no response) Suit yourself. ABBY slides THERESE’S plate to her side of the table and starts finishing it. THERESE turns to her.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Why don’t you like me? I’ve never done anything to you. A pause. ABBY starts to say something, thinks better of i She leans in towards THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: You really think I’ve flown halfway across the country to drive you back East because I hate you and want to see you suffer?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It’s for Carol. Not for me.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: (after a beat) That’s - If you really believe that then you’re not as smart as I thought you were. Therese takes this in, then looks up at Abby. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: With you and Carol... what happened?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: It’s completely different - I’ve known Carol since I was 10 years old... (after a long beat) It was... back when we had the furniture store. Late one night. My Ford broke down near my Mother’s house and... We tried to stay up, but... curled up together in my old twin bed. And that was it... Fora while. And then it changed. It changes. Nobody’s fault. (beat) So... She opens her purse and searches inside. She produces an envelope.  95

dialogues.speaker: ABBY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here - she...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: What? ABBY hands her a letter. EXT. ROADSIDE DINER. MOMENTS LATER. In a WIDE lonely frame we see THERESE has stepped outside diner to tear open the letter. As she reads, we hear CARO voice:

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Dearest. There are no accidents and he would have found us one way or another. Everything comes full circle. Be grateful it was sooner rather than later. You’1l think it harsh of me to say so, but no explanation I offer will satisfy you. We see ABBY leave the diner as THERESE continues reading. climbs in the car and starts the engine. A soft undertone MUSIC has emerged. INT. ANOTHER MOTEL. NIGHT. ABBY in the bathroom, washing out some clothes. Through a crack in the door, she spots THERESE, seated on the bed, drained by tears, expressionless.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Please don’t be angry when I tell you that you seek resolutions and explanations because you’re young. But you will understand this one day. INT./EXT. COUNTRY ROAD. DAY. ABBY pulls the car off the road near a small grove of tre and fading clumps of snow. THERESE jumps out, makes for t trees and tries to hide herself before she throws up. ABB lights a cigarette and remains in the car, watching THERE from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: And when it happens, I want you to imagine me there to greet you like the morning sky, our lives stretched out ahead of us, a perpetual sunrise.  96 INT. CAROL’S CAR. NIGHT. ABBY, at the wheel, glances in the rear-view-mirror at THERESE, stretched out asleep on the back seat of the car Distant passing lights comb over her repose.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: But until then, there must be no contact between us. I have much to do, and you, my darling, even more. Please believe that I would do anything to see you happy and so I do the only thing I can - I release you. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. NEW YORK. DAY. THERESE, in her overcoat, suitcase beside her, stands in middle of her apartment. It’s full of her things, but it looks like a foreign land. All the photographs on the wal seem as if they were taken by someone else. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. THAT SAME NIGHT. THERESE hunches over her sink, bathed in red light. She t a quick deep drag of a cigarette, burning in an ashtray. of negatives hang from hooks underneath the kitchen cupboards, over the trays of chemicals. She finds a certa shot on the enlarger, marks it, and focuses. She begins t process of developing the print. Finally, she watches the photo in its bath slowly appear shadow here and there, a shape forming - and it’s CAROL, asleep on her back, her body akimbo in a tumble of sheets one hand resting delicately. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY. LATE NIGHT. THERESE is creeping down the half-lit stairway. She picks the phone without making a sound and stares at the dial. hangs up. Then in one continuous gesture she picks it up again and dials the number. She stands frozen. One long r Silence. Another long ring. Then someone picks up the lin But there’s silence on the other end. Nothing. THERESE is frozen.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Hello? (beat) Carol? The silence that follows is like an answer. THERESE holds receiver close: a precious thing.  97 INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. KITCHEN. NIGHT. CAROL in the dark, on the other end, still. She makes a movement as if to say something, but doesn’t. We see her finger softly graze the receiver button before pressing i down. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT BUILDING. HALLWAY PHONE. NIGHT. Extremely CLOSE on THERESE hearing CAROL disconnect, but holding on in the void.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (prayerful) I miss you. I miss you. INT. HARGE’S PARENTS HOUSE. NEW JERSEY. DAY. HARGE, CAROL, JENNIFER and JOHN are seated together for a weekday lunch, with everything distinctly in its place. Eisenhower's inauguration proceedings can be heard and glimpsed on the living room television set.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: More mashed potatoes, Carol?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Yes - Thanks. They’re delicious. CAROL reaches over to take the bowl of mashed potatoes, b HARGE gets to it first, spoons some out for CAROL. The atmosphere is polite, but far from relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. (beat) I thought... perhaps... Chester and Marge would be here by now. With Rindy...

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Marge said to go ahead, not to wait.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (to CAROL) I’m sure they’1l be here soon. CAROL appreciates HARGE’S small kindness.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: Harge tells us you’ve been getting along quite well with your doctor, Carol.  98

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: And why shouldn’t she be getting on well. He’s a very expensive doctor.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: He’s actually not a doctor but a psychotherapist.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Well he comes very well regarded.

dialogues.speaker: JOHN
dialogues.text: (to HARGE) A Yale man, like your uncle.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (ever so slightly edgy) But that doesn’t make him a doctor. HARGE throws her a little look.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I do like him. Very much. He’s been a great help. JENNIFER and JOHN continue eating in silence. INT. HARGE’S PARENTS HOUSE. LATER. CAROL sits alone near the living room window, caught in a stare. She’s jolted out of it by the sound of JENNIFER, approaching with a cup of tea. CAROL turns.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Thank you Jennifer, but I’m fine, really-

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: It‘ll calm your nerves. JENNIFER sets it down on a small end table, and places a on CAROL’s shoulder. Just then we hear the sound of a car coming up the drive.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: They’re here. CAROL rises, gives her hair a quick pat and starts off to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Just a moment, dear. CAROL stops, turns. JENNIFER walks over to where CAROL st her and adjusts her collar.  99 CAROL manages to maintain composure, then turn from JENNI and continues on to the door. EXT. HARGE’S PARENTS HOUSE. LATE AFTERNOON/EARLY EVENING. CONTINUOUS. CAROL runs to greet RINDY, who walks hand-in-hand with a MIDDLE AGED COUPLE, RINDY’S AUNT AND UNCLE. When she sees Mother, RINDY lets go of their hands and runs towards CAR They meet. CAROL kneels down and sweeps RINDY into her ar She hugs her tightly, holding on for dear life.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh baby... my baby girl... INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. AFTERNOON. DANNIE is over, helping THERESE repaint her apartment. THERESE is on a ladder, painting some molding near the ceiling and DANNIE is below. As the RADIO plays ("Lullaby Birdland” by Georges Shearing), DANNIE spots THERESE wipi sweat from her brow. They’ve clearly been at it a while.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: I think it’s break time. Let me fetch some brews.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Sounds good. DANNIE goes to the kitchen to grab some beers and an open THERESE has been developing more photos - almost all of t pictures of CAROL from their trip. DANNIE can’t help but a look. He hears something behind him and turns. It’s THERESE.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: These are seriously good. I mean, they really capture - whoever this is.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: They're just practice. THERESE crosses the room and begins picking up the pictur tidying the area.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: You really should put together a portfolio. Say the word, I’1l introduce you to my pal at the Times. There’s always a clerk job going.  100 THERESE shakes her head, takes the pictures into the othe room and s pulls open a drawer to stash them in. DANNIE (CONT’D) You went away with her, right?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Ohh. Nothing. It’s - hard to...

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Is it because I tried to kiss you that day? Because if it is, don’t even think about that, I mean, don’t be afraid of-

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m not afraid. THERESE is stopped a moment by her own words, reminding h of another time and place. She looks back at him. THERESE (CONT’D) Let’s finish while we still have light, okay? DANNIE shrugs and they get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: I still think you should put together that portfolio. INT. THERESE’S APARTMENT. LATE NIGHT. THERESE sits on her kitchen floor sorting photographs, a cigarette burning in an ashtray beside her. She’s busy placing them into neat piles. We see her older work - LANDSCAPES, STILL LIFE’S, ARCHITECTURAL DETAILS - and all newer work - PHOTOS OF KIDS PLAYING IN THE STREET, OLD WO DRAGGING SHOPPING CARTS, CITY FACES - virtually all of th depicting people. At the bottom of one pile she discovers picture of CAROL BUYING THE XMAS TREE. She considers it a moment before pulling it out of the stack. EXT. CENTRAL PARK. A FEW DAYS LATER. AFTERNOON. It’s a gray, rainy day at the park. Walkers with umbrella RICHARD has brought THERESE a box of her belongings.  101

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Everything's there. (beat) My mother washed and ironed your blouses.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Thank her for me?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You can thank her yourself.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Richard...

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: What do you expect me to say? I mean... You never even wrote- THERESE looks away.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I tried, I just... I couldn’t find the words. She tries to touch his shoulder, he moves away from her.

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Please don’t touch me. (he shakes his head). After what we had - after what you did... Throwing it all away.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: What did we have?

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: Thanks, that’s...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No - tell me!

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: You tell me, Terry. Did you - did you love me even a little? They hold a look, but THERESE can’t hurt him like this. S turns away.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Please, please don’t hate me. I’m still... me. Still the same person I always was.  102

dialogues.speaker: RICHARD
dialogues.text: No. You’re not, alright? You’re someone else now. And I can’t. I can’t forgive you. (beat) So long, Terry. A beat, before RICHARD leaves. THERESE doesn’t move. INT. CAROL’S HOUSE. DUSK. CAROL sits in the lantern seat off her stairway, looking at the night. From down below she hears the RADIO REPORT blaring on, announcing the death of Stalin. The radio is lowered and CAROL looks down. She sees Abby starting up the stairs with two cups of coffee. CAROL sta down to meet her.

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Stay. Stay.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly. She takes her cup from ABBY and starts back up to her sea CAROL returns to where she was sitting and ABBY sits on t stairs below her. ABBY can read CAROL’s despondency from mile away.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I don’t know if I can do it, Abby. What more can I do? How many more - tomato aspic lunches... just to come home every night without her. To this!

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: And... Therese?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: What about her?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: Have you - heard anything?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Oh no. No. It’s been over a month since she tried to call. Nothing since then. I wish I... (but she stops, then): Have you? Heard anything?  103

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: From Therese? No. (beat) She must have started her job at the Times, though. That’s something.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I should have said: Therese. Wait. ABBY reaches out, puts a hand on CAROL’S foot. All at onc pair of headlights swing by, lighting up the windows, and they are jolted. CAROL turns and ABBY stands, startled. A look between them: is someone here? Is this trouble? And the headlights disappear.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Who the hell is turning around in my drive?

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: I should go.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You don’t have to-

dialogues.speaker: ABBY
dialogues.text: -I do. ABBY squeezes CAROL’S hand - courage. And they start down stairs together. EXT. HUDSON RIVER PIER. NEW YORK. NIGHT. DANNIE and THERESE sit together on the pier, looking acro the river to New Jersey.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: I’m glad you called... I never see you no more! Now that you’ve got the fancy job with the smooth hours. You punch out, I punch in.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: It doesn’t feel fancy, hauling gallon jugs of developer all day. But I kind of love it, you know?

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: Sure. (beat) Hey - guess what happened to me? No? Can’t think of it? THERESE smiles, shakes her head.  104 DANNIE (CONT’D) I met a girl. Louise. She’s got green eyes, she’s a movie encyclopedia, and the most amazing thing? She thinks I’m boss.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (she’s pleased for DANNIE) Go figure.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (he’s pleased she’s Pleased) Yeah. (beat) If you want, we can all hang out some night. Go to a movie.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: That sounds swell. I’d love to meet her. (pause) Did, uh - Have you seen Richard?

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: I seen him. (beat) Think he wanted to talk, maybe. But I, uh... I don’t know. I feel bad for him. But I don’t wanna get- He stops, glancing up at THERESE, then looking away. THERESE’s thoughts seem to harden and a brief darkness fa over her.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Use what feels right. Throw away the rest.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (laughs) Where’d that come from?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Something Carol once said to me.

dialogues.speaker: DANNIE
dialogues.text: (a beat, then: ) Did she... do that? To you? THERESE struggles for this...

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I can’t - go. Back. To that place. Where you keep it all locked up... the sadness, shame... You let people down. You let yourself - down. So you cry and you... hide and think - things, constantly, crazy things, like... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: THERESE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: if you stare at the phone long enough or - take a train and just... lurk... it could all... return. (silence) And then one day the phone is just a phone. A train going to Jersey is just a train to Jersey. You stop - crying and hiding. And you know you’re able to use things and throw them away. The river looks like a swath of black cellophane.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
