dialogues.text: INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. (APRIL 1953) THERESE sits on the edge of the bathtub next to the open window, taking in the air. She can hear the party in progress, people having a great time, but she’s not ready rejoin them. A couple of RAPID KNOCKS on the door.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Sorry. Just a second. THERESE gathers herself, gets up, opens the door. It’s GENEVIEVE. She wears her coat and scarf. THERESE (CONT’D) Oh. You’re leaving.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: Just about. Will you miss me? THERESE doesn’t look away from GENEVIEVE this time. GENEV moves closer to THERESE, whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen, Therese. There’s an intime gathering, quite exclusive you understand, later on. At my place. (beat) Quick. Show me your hand.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You a fortune teller?

dialogues.speaker: GENEVIEVE
dialogues.text: I’m a fortune giver. GENEVIEVE takes THERESE’S hand, writes her address in ink onto THERESE’S palm. GENEVIEVE (CONT’D) So you don’t forget.  106 And GENEVIEVE'S off. THERESE watches her wind her way to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through passing cars and car windows we suddenly see THER dressed for work in a smart dark suit, hurrying through t morning commuter CROWD towards the New York Times buildin Her style of hair and dress has taken on a sophistication maturity we can’t help but associate with CAROL. INT. TAXI. TIMES SQUARE. MORNING. CAROL, in the cab on her way to FRED HAYMES’S office, is looking distantly out the window when she suddenly spots The light changes and the taxi starts to move - THERESE flickers from view. CAROL looks back over her shoulder through reflections. INT. ELEVATOR/JERRY RIX LAW OFFICES. DAY. CAROL, turned away, inside the elevator. The doors open. turns to look a moment before heading out the door and do the hall. Gathered inside, HARGE, RIX, FRED HAYMES and a STENOGRAPH all turn and note her arrival.

dialogues.speaker: INT. JERRY RIX LAW OFFICES. DAY. MOMENTS LATER
dialogues.text: Everyone is gathered around the conference table.

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIX
dialogues.text: Well-(coughs)- we feel, given the seriousness of the charges and the incontestability of the evidence, my client has every reason to expect a compliant and favorable outcome.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: Not so fast, Jerry. My client’s psychotherapist is perfectly satisfied with her recovery from... the events of the winter, asserting she’s more than capable of caring for her child. She’s had no further contact with Therese Belivet. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silence, 107

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And we have sworn depositions from two Saddlebrook Institute psychiatrists clearly stating that, in their opinions, a series of events, precipitated by my client’s husband, drove her to suffer an emotional break, which resulted in this - described behavior.

dialogues.speaker: HARGE
dialogues.text: (looks to his lawyer for help) That's absurd! - Are they serious-?

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIX
dialogues.text: Alright, Fred - okay, if this is how you’re going to play this-

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: Furthermore, given the manner in which these tapes were obtained and recorded, we’re confident in their inadmissability-

dialogues.speaker: JERRY RIX
dialogues.text: Okay, okay. First off, I’d like to see these depositions. And second-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (interrupts him) Fred - please. Don’t - May I speak? as everybody in the room looks to CAROL.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I won’t deny the truth of what’s contained in those tapes.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES
dialogues.text: (signals to the

dialogues.speaker: STENOGRAPHER
dialogues.text: This is off the record, honey.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Might as well be on the record. A pause as JERRY nods to the STENOGRAPHER to continue and CAROL pours herself a glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wanted - I did want - to talk about... duty... sacrifice. That was what I-(beat)... But now that I’m here I don’t... I don’t know what I believe... Or what I even know... except that... (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know I want to see my daughter - to hear her voice... Always. To be there when she’s- She stops, holding back tears, which she refuses to allow Gathering herself, she levels her eyes directly to Harge, makes her case directly to him.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harge, I want you to be... happy. I didn’t give you that - I failed you - we both could have... given. More. (beat) But we gave each other Rindy, and that’s - the most - breathtaking, the most... generous... of gifts. (beat) So why are we spending so much time... coming up with ways to keep her from each other. (beat) What happened with Therese... I wanted. I won’t deny it or- HARGE looks down.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +. But I do regret, I - grieve... the mess we’re about to make... of our child’s life. We, Harge... we are both... responsible. Let’s... set it right. (beat) I want Harge to have... permanent custody- Amidst the sudden chaos HARGE’s eyes take hold of her and don’t let up.

dialogues.speaker: FRED HAYMES JERRY RIX
dialogues.text: Let’s take a break, folks and Fred - no, I think your resume when I’ve had a moment client has made it perfectl to confer with my- clear given her statement-

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, Fred. Let me have my say. Because - if you stop me... I won't... be able... to cope... CAROL stands, stepping away from the table, to regain her composure. Silence returns before she continues. CAROL (CONT’D) I’m no martyr. I have no clue... what’s best for me. But I do know... I feel, I feel it in my bones... what’s best for my daughter. She starts to turn and walk again, addressing HARGE.  109

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) I want visits with her, Harge. I don’t care if they’re supervised. But they need to be regular. (beat) There was a time... I would have locked myself away - done most anything... just to keep Rindy with me. But... what use am I to her... to us... living against... my own grain? Rindy deserves - joy. How do I give her that not knowing what it means... myself. She pours herself another glass of water.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s the deal. Take it or leave it. I can’t - I won’t negotiate. If you... leave it, we go to court and it gets ugly. We’re not ugly people, Harge. Feeling suddenly shaky she turns and starts out of the ro HARGE stands, staring at her as she goes, as FRED leaps t his feet and hurries after her, calling her name. EXT. COFFEE SHOP. SEVENTH AVENUE. DAY. Through reflections we see CAROL seated at a table, writi note. Beside her a pot of coffee and cigarette burning in ashtray. She signs it. Seals it inside an envelope, and begins gathering her things. INT. NEW YORK TIMES. PHOTO DEPARTMENT. DAY. THERESE organizes black and white prints during a meeting photo editors, gathered around a large table. Smoke in th air. Through the glass a MESSENGER is seen speaking to a CLERK. The CLERK spots THERESE inside the room and brings the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Belivet. THERESE, looks up, and hurries over to the CLERK by the d He hands her the envelope.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hand delivered. Swank. THERESE takes the envelope and returns to the table. Glan down, she recognizes CAROL'S handwriting.  110 INT. NEW YORK TIMES. PHOTO DEPARTMENT. LATER. THERESE types labels at her cubicle. The open note sits beside her on her desk. She stops typing and looks over a the note. She picks it up and holds it for a moment befor crumpling it up and tossing it into a desk drawer. She returns to typing. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. NIGHT. CAROL is entering the hotel from the street entrance, removing her scarf and adjusting her hair. She makes her to the pay telephones and slips inside an empty booth. Th we see her dial a number and make a quick call. She hangs takes out her compact and powders her nose. She steps out the booth and stops. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. BAR/LOUNGE. NIGHT. There, across the room, is THERESE being shown to a corne table, THERESE looking more grown-up and put together, THERESE thanking the MAITRE D’, THERESE sitting down... C takes a breath, then makes her way across the room. THERESE looks up and sees her.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I wasn’t sure you'd come. It’s nice of you to see me.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Don’t say that. CAROL settles in opposite THERESE, moving her coat aside.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Do you hate me, Therese?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No. How could I hate you?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I suppose you could. Didn’t you? For a while? THERESE looks down. She pours herself some tea.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Abby tells me you’re thriving. You've no idea how pleased I am for you. (beat) You look very fine, you know. As if you’ve suddenly blossomed. Is that what comes of getting away from me?  111

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (answers quickly) No. She frowns, regretting answering so quickly, and looking down. When she looks up again, CAROL is staring at her, quite intently. THERESE (CONT’D) What?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Nothing. I was just thinking about that day. In the doll department.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I always wondered... Why did you come over to me?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Because you were the only girl not busy as hell. (beat) Disappointed? THERESE shakes her head no. CAROL smiles at the memory an lights a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Harge and I are selling the house. I’ve taken an apartment. On Madison Avenue. And a job, believe it or not. I’m going to work for a furniture house on Fourth Avenue as a buyer. Some of my ancestors must have been carpenters. THERESE gives CAROL a little smile - a bit of thaw.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Have you seen Rindy?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (after a beat) Once or twice. At the lawyer’s office. She sat on my lap and we... (holding THERESE’S gaze): She's going to live with Harge. For now. It’s... the right thing. CAROL can’t quite cover the pain of this, but she tries.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, the apartment’s a nice big one - big enough for two. I was hoping you might like to come and live with me, but I guess you won't. (beat) Would you?  112 A held breath.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: No. I don’t think so.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: That's... your decision.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Yes. A silence.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: I’m meeting some people from the furniture house at the Oak Room at nine. If you want to have dinner... if you change your mind... I think-- you'd like them. (beat) Well. That’s that. CAROL puts out her cigarette, stares at her cigarette lig on the table.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I love you. A silence. THERESE wants to say something, but can’t.

dialogues.speaker: O/S JACK TAFT
dialogues.text: Therese? Is that you? And the moment is gone. THERESE looks up, turns towards t source of the greeting. It’s a smiling JACK TAFT, halfway across the room, near t bar.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What do you know! (starts over) I’m saying to myself, I know that girl. THERESE watches JACK make his way over to her. She gives CAROL a quick look - CAROL, staring down at the table, no knowing what to do, vulnerable... THERESE rises to greet JACK.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Gee but it’s great to see you. It’s been, well, months.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Months.  113 CAROL lights a cigarette. THERESE glances at her, and the hold a look for a moment before THERESE speaks. THERESE (CONT’D) Jack, this is Carol Aird. JACK holds out his hand. CAROL shakes it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Likewise. CAROL retreats back to her own thoughts, smokes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey, Ted Gray’s meeting me here and a bunch of us are heading down to Phil’s party. You’re going aren’t you?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: Well - yes. I just planned to get there a little...(looking to Carol)

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You should go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You coming along?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: No, no. (to THERESE) I should make a few calls before dinner, anyway. I should really run.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: You sure?

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: (to JACK) Well... it would be great to catch a ride. CAROL takes a step towards THERESE, but no more.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: You two have a wonderful night. Nice meeting you, Jack.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Nice meeting you.  114 And she’s gone. THERESE doesn’t move, doesn’t turn around watch CAROL leave.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Alright, well let me go make sure the loaf is on his way. Back ina flash. And JACK’S off to the phone booth. A beat, before THERESE turns around. She scans the bar and beyond for CAROL, but she’s not there. THERESE walks to the lobby entrance - sh scans the lobby - but CAROL is well and truly gone - and only now hits THERESE that she let CAROL walk away. THERE turns and makes her way to the LADIES ROOM in a bit of a daze. INT. RITZ TOWER HOTEL. LADIES ROOM. NIGHT. THERESE stands at the sink, water running. She can barely bring herself to look into the mirror. She splashes cold water on her face. INT. PHIL’S APARTMENT. NIGHT. THERESE threads her way through PHIL’S GUESTS on her way the front door - it’s no easy task navigating, especially since no one seems to notice THERESE, or anything other t their own good time. When she finally reaches the door, THERESE takes a look back into the living room to see if she’s missed out on any good-byes. She spots DANNIE and LOUISE on the floor, knees-up to PHIL’S small black and w TV set, intently watching a film, oblivious to the noise around them. DANNIE jots notes every once in a while in h little notebook. All seems right here - for others at lea THERESE slips out the door. EXT. GREENWICH VILLAGE STREET. NIGHT. THERESE walks down a quaint, cobbled street. It’s a lovel night and there are various PEDESTRIANS out strolling. It seems to THERESE that she’s the only person who isn’t smiling, isn’t engaged with someone who’s actually beside on such a lovely evening. She looks at the palm of her ha checks the address, keeps walking. As she approaches the address, THERESE spots an ELDERLY COUPLE arm in arm, supporting each other, walking down the street towards he They look like they’ve been together for ever: the ELDERL WOMAN leaning in to her husband as they pass, the ELDERLY tipping his hat to THERESE. We HEAR SHARP LAUGHTER from a nearby apartment and THERES turns to see GENEVIEVE CANTRELL lean backwards out of a window. She holds a bottle of champagne which spills down into the street below.  115 GENEVIEVE gestures to someone inside, and ANOTHER WOMAN j GENEVIEVE at the window - the two begin to make out. THER watches their embrace for a moment; it’s tremendously sex GENEVIEVE pulls the WOMAN back into the apartment, and th window’s slammed shut behind them. The night is suddenly quiet. THERESE looks off in the direction the ELDERLY COU took. She starts walking, away from GENEVIEVE, toward something else. She begins to walk more quickly, and more quickly still, brushing past the world of strangers. INT. THE OAK ROOM. PLAZA HOTEL. NIGHT. THERESE, winded, enters the restaurant. A WAITER stops he

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: Do you have a reservation?

dialogues.speaker: THERESE
dialogues.text: I’m looking for someone.

dialogues.speaker: WAITER
dialogues.text: I'm sorry ma’am, I can’t seat you without- She moves away from the WAITER and scans the crowded room Nothing. Then, out of the corner of her eye, almost imperceptible at first, at a table towards the rear of th room, she sees a woman’s blonde head thrown back in laugh the woman seems to be encapsulated in or protected by a h of light and smoke. It’s CAROL, CAROL as THERESE has alwa seen her and as she will see her evermore: in SLOW MOTION like in a dream or a single, defining memory, substantial elusive. She moves towards her. CAROL raises a wine glass her lips and as she does, she turns slightly and spots THERESE. She is not startled. We see her face softening. THERESE continues to approach. CAROL watches with a smile burning in her eyes. THERESE has nearly arrived.

dialogues.speaker: BEST ADAPTED SCREENPLAY
dialogues.text: Phyllis Nagy y

dialogues.speaker: THE WEINSTEIN COMPANY
dialogues.text: www.TWCAwards.com
